data.title: The monstrous landlord who had plenty of lovers and hundreds of properties
data.description:
When I was young – and possibly when you were young – a “Rachman” was a common term for a bad landlord. “He’s a right old Rachman” was shorthand for someone being exploitative, intimidating and otherwise unhelpful. We owe the term, for those still too young to know, to Peter Rachman, the Polish-born Jewish Holocaust survivor who reinvented himself as a west London wheeler-dealer, and who for years was regarded as the epitome of everything rotten in post-war Britain.

In Slumlord, Neil Root successfully prises the human being out from under the epithet, and, in the process, re-opens the door on one of those small dark rooms in recent history that we would perhaps all rather forget. Root is certainly suited to the job. A long-time and prolific true-crime writer, he has written about all sorts of corrupt detectives, wrong’uns and dodgy dealers, skilfully placing them in their wider historical context. With Slumlord, he does the same again, describing in detail the scale of Rachman’s property empire, as well as setting his activities against the backdrop of the darker glamour of his age: Christine Keeler and Mandy Rice-Davies, Ronnie and Reggie Kray, and so on.

The bare bones of the story have been told before – in books, in documentaries and, perhaps most unexpectedly, in Caryl Phillips’s recent novel Another Man in the Street (2025), which features a thinly fictionalised version of Rachman as Phillips’s landlord character, Feldman. Born Perec Rachman in Lwów in 1919, Rachman endured Nazi and then Soviet camps before fighting with the Polish forces alongside the Allies. After demobilisation in Britain, he drifted into the West London property market, beginning modestly as an estate agent’s assistant, and ending by the late 1950s with more than 100 decrepit mansion blocks and a Rolls-Royce.

The crucial move in Rachman’s rapid ascent was his exploitation of Britain’s convoluted rent-control regime. Protected, mostly white, working class tenants were bought off, bullied out, or concentrated into a smaller pool of properties; their places in formerly respectable terraces were taken by recent West Indian migrants who enjoyed almost no legal protection and could be charged extortionate rents for squalid little rooms. Rachman would rely on a ruthless “heavy crew”, a threatening bunch of pretty-boy wrestlers who liked to turn up with Alsatians in order to sort out any troublesome tenants.

The story, in Root’s telling, very much represents the shadow side of Swinging London. Rachman appears at the edge of the Profumo affair: he kept models (and lovers) Rice-Davies and Keeler at a Marylebone mews house which he owned, a convenient pied-à-terre where sex, politics and class briefly collided. (Sex for Rachman, Keeler said, “was like cleaning his teeth, and I was the toothpaste”.)

He did business with the Krays, handing them the Knightsbridge club Esmeralda’s Barn in lieu of allowing them to muscle in on his property holdings. And Michael de Freitas, later known as Michael X, the black revolutionary, was one of his rent collectors. The person that emerges from this milieu is a disturbingly contradictory figure: a Jewish refugee, rendered stateless, whose life circumstances hardened both into a predatory indifference to others’ needs, but who also afforded housing opportunities to other immigrants.

Root’s instinct is to distrust both hagiography and demonology and doggedly to follow the paper trail – perhaps, at times, a little too doggedly. There’s extensive quoting of archive material, interviews and much following of the fortunes of minor characters. Sometimes the reader might yearn for the narrative to slow down: “In the mid-to-late 1950s, Rachman was close friends with Denis Hamilton, the first husband of the film star Diana Dors, before she had a relationship with Rachman’s employee Tommy Yeardye.” Root weaves his way expertly, swiftly, through ledger books, shell companies, council reports, Hansard debates, court records and foggy memories from ex-tenants and ex-gangsters, often leaving the reader panting to catch up.

The book is at its most compelling when Root pauses for long enough to analyse Rachman’s behaviour. He portrays it as a kind of extreme expression of a system designed to further disadvantage those already disadvantaged by the chronic post-war housing shortage, the perverse incentives of rent control, and the political reluctance to act until scandal forced Parliament’s hand and the 1965 Rent Act finally strengthened tenant protections. But then the book’s pace soon picks up again: Root is, after all, a true-crime writer, and readers looking for an extended engagement with housing theory, the history of race relations, or the economic history of post-war London will want to look elsewhere.

If Root succeeds, it is in showing how a single individual managed to exploit the faults and flaws in a rotten system. In an age when rogue landlords still fill the headlines, and London’s rental market remains cheerfully sadistic, “Rachmanism” clearly remains with us. Slumlord is not, therefore, just a lurid period piece or a glimpse of some dim, unpleasant past, but an unsettling mirror held up to the city’s present.

★★★☆☆

Slumlord is published by Icon at £20. To order your copy, call 0330 173 0523 or visit Telegraph Books

data.title: Village green preservation society at war over plans for block of flats
data.description:
Fears that dozens of luxury apartments could be erected on their beloved village green have prompted residents of Tunbridge Wells to launch a campaign for its preservation.

The town’s common land has been put up for sale, with part of the 256-acre stretch of Kent heathland and woods being offered to potential buyers as a “prime redevelopment opportunity” for residential properties.

Targetfollow, a property development company that has owned the Tunbridge Wells and Rusthall Commons since 2008, has said that an existing car park could be turned into a £60m residential development.

So disgusted are the spa town’s residents at the prospect, many are prepared to put their hands in their pockets to buy the Commons in a bid to foil the threat of any future development of one of the town’s most attractive outdoor areas.

Faced with the threat of development, campaigners are taking up as their anthem the Kinks’ 1968 classic The Village Green Preservation Society.

The Friends of Tunbridge Wells and Rusthall Commons (FTWRC) has launched a crowdfunding drive to raise £1.5m to buy the land and manage it for the “benefit of the community”.

The Tunbridge Wells and Rusthall Commons has enjoyed village green status since the mid-19th century, with strict conservation laws barring any development.

But FTWRC fears that Emma Reynolds, the Environment Secretary, could waive its protection, which would allow building on part of the Commons to go ahead.

The group also worries that any approval of the redevelopment proposals could open the door to more projects elsewhere on the Commons.

Targetfollow has told potential buyers they could apply to the Secretary of State to deregister the Upper Pantiles Car Park as a protected site, in exchange for introducing safeguards for a “comparable parcel” of land at nearby Still Green.

If approved, this would allow redevelopment to take place, with initial design studies suggesting capacity for 104 luxury apartments and 285 parking spaces overlooking the rest of the Commons close to the Pantiles, the Georgian colonnaded walkway – which is also owned by Targetfollow.

Roger Barton, the treasurer of FTWRC, said: “This would be an unsightly residential development on what is supposed to be green common land.

“Like many residents, most people assumed the Commons were publicly owned, so the news of their sale has come as a surprise and prompted a strong local response.”

He added: “It raises the question of who our shared landscapes really belong to, what ownership means in practice and how communities respond when places they love are treated as market assets.

“This is about long-term stewardship. The Commons are deeply valued locally, and we are exploring whether community ownership could provide certainty for future generations.”

The crowdfunding campaign has already raised around half a million pounds in pledges, but FTWRC only has until March 26 to come up with the full amount needed to outbid other potential buyers.

John Barber, the former chairman of FTWRC, said: “As a community we feel this is a real opportunity to take the Commons into community ownership for the first time ever.

“I’d say more than 90 per cent of people are against any prospect of building on the Commons. Should permission be granted in this case, it risks opening the door to further development in future.”

Mr Barber said the campaign would be happy to invite Ray Davies, who wrote The Village Green Preservation Society, to perform the song at one of their forthcoming campaign events “as long as he’s prepared to put his hand in his pocket to support our buy-out”.

“He could even write a song about our campaign. I’d have thought it was the kind of subject matter he might be interested in,” Mr Barber added.

Targetfollow, a Norwich-based asset acquisition group, describes the sale of the Commons as “a truly unique opportunity in the heart of Kent” in its brochure.

It states that with the necessary planning consent, the six-acre car park and adjacent woodland would provide a “prime redevelopment opportunity” and “a rare chance to transform a high-profile central site into an exceptional address”.

The brochure said applying for the land exchange “would unlock significant development potential, enabling a planning application for a scheme comparable to The Potteries”, and a residential development at its full capacity would have a projected gross development value of around £60m and a residual site value of approximately £10m.

Purchase of the Commons would also include the title of Lord of the Manor of Rusthall, an ancient feudal holding extending from London Road in Tunbridge Wells westward to Langton Green and northward to Speldhurst.

Targetfollow said it was looking for a buyer “who will act as a responsible long-term steward of this historic landscape and will respect the Commons’ protections and community value”.

Corin Thoday, the chief executive of Targetfollow, said in a statement announcing the sale last October: “The Commons are a cherished part of Tunbridge Wells. Our role now is to run a fair, transparent process that identifies a buyer committed to long-term responsible stewardship – whoever and wherever they are.”

Targetfollow said: “In order for any development to take place on the car park which forms part of Tunbridge Wells Common, an application to deregister and exchange that part of the Common would be necessary, and this would require the approval of the Secretary of State, following which full planning would be required.

“We are aware the local community groups are working on raising funds to exercise their Right to Bid – all offers will be considered.”

data.title: HSBC scrambles to stave off BrewDog losses
data.description:
HSBC is scrambling to avoid steep losses on tens of millions of pounds of loans to BrewDog as the craft beer business faces a potential break-up.

The banking giant has secured its debts against BrewDog’s sprawling Scottish brewery, giving it the right to seize the property if necessary.

HSBC’s race to secure its loans comes after the struggling brewer recently launched a quick-fire sale process overseen by restructuring experts AlixPartners.

It has prompted fears of losses for investors and creditors alike. The bank is BrewDog’s main lender.

The move came as it emerged that James Watt, Brewdog’s co-founder, is preparing to invest £10m of his own cash into a rescue bid for the group.

Mr Watt is assembling a consortium of investors to acquire the entire group, including its bars, brands and brewing facilities, Sky News reported. The identity of the backers is still unclear.

Security against the brewery gives HSBC greater protection in the event that a sale fails and the company falls into administration.

Recent filings show HSBC’s loans have been secured against BrewDog’s flagship brewery in Ellon, Aberdeenshire. The site, which also includes a distillery and bar, opened in 2012 and produces hundreds of millions of litres of beer annually, including best-selling brands such as Punk IPA and Hazy Jane.

Allan Leighton, the chairman of BrewDog, signed off on HSBC’s claim against the brewery earlier this month.

The additional security comes as the craft beer pioneer races to find a rescuer for its business. A second round of bidding is expected to begin in the coming days.

A break-up of the loss-making company is seen as likely, with the brewing operation separated from BrewDog’s dozens of bars.

Any sale will be complicated by an unusual arrangement between the company and its private equity backers TSG Consumer Partners.

TSG ploughed £213m into BrewDog in 2017 to secure a 21pc stake but this included a clause guaranteeing the fund an 18pc compounding rate of return on its investment.

The arrangement has saddled BrewDog with debts of more than £800m to TSG, meaning any sale must exceed that figure if other investors are to realise a return. The most recent crowdfunding valued the business at £2bn, although any sale is expected to be well below that price.

It is understood that the company’s brand and breweries are the most attractive assets for potential buyers. Its pubs and bars are less appealing in the wake of tax increases by Rachel Reeves, the Chancellor, which piled pressure on the hospitality sector by driving up costs.

Potential suitors include drinks giants Carlsberg, Heineken and AB InBev, the brewing giant behind Stella Artois and Corona.

Company filings show that BrewDog currently has £92m in outstanding bank loans including £25m due for repayment in six months.

HSBC has backed BrewDog for more than a decade. Mr Watt claimed in 2015 that he had blagged his way to securing an early loan from the bank.

Mr Watt said at the time: “We said that our bank had offered us an amazing deal but that if you can match it we’ll switch and they went for it. You have got to do what you have to do.”

Mark Tate, formerly an executive at HSBC, said in 2013 that BrewDog “is exactly the sort of business we are well placed to serve”.

As well as bank loans, Mr Watt also raised £75m from an army of 200,000 “punk equity investors”. These smaller shareholders are now likely to be wiped out as part of any sale.

Mr Watt, who stepped down as chief executive in 2024 but retains a 22pc stake, is also believed to be rallying his own bid to regain control. However, he has yet to reveal his financial backers.

The scramble to restore BrewDog’s fortunes follows years of losses. The company lost £37m in 2024-25 on revenues of £357m.

Problems have been compounded by slowing sales growth, fuelled by a cost-of-living squeeze and young people drinking less.

Even Mr Watt has admitted to drinking less beer as part of a health kick, limiting himself to between six and eight units a week. One pint of BrewDog Punk IPA contains just above three units of alcohol.

HSBC and BrewDog declined to comment.

data.title: Have a budget of £200m? This London home with secret corridors is on the market
data.description:
The super-rich, we’re told, are leaving London. Since Brexit, the arrival of Labour and the non-dom debacle, they’re buying into the sun-baked bling of Dubai, Monaco or Marbella, and they’re sampling the tax-friendly carrots being dangled in Italy.

There is a house in a Mayfair garden square, however, that might tempt an ultra-high-net-worth individual to stay. In St James’s Square, steps from the historic In & Out Club, which counts royalty among its members, an eight-storey house spanning 30,000sq ft (a largish family house would be swallowed up by the 3,500sq ft master suite alone) has discreetly become available to buy.

‘I suspect its price will start with a two,’ states its casually dressed and well-connected 44-year-old developer, Dean Main, who wears two hats in the super-prime property sphere: he is founder of Henigman, a private investment and development company that undertook this lavish redevelopment project; he is also founder and CEO of Rhodium, which manages many of London’s most upmarket developments (The Bryanston, 60 Curzon, Lancer Square) – which will come in handy when whoever buys this gargantuan house needs a ready supply of butlers, cooks and security guards.

Main doesn’t need to say it, but following the ‘two’ he mentions are eight zeros, as this isn’t merely one of the biggest houses in London, it’s one of the most expensive, on- or off-market. Assuming this won’t be someone’s only residence, and that its eventual buyer is likely to be a non-UK resident (viewers so far have come from the US, Middle East and India), the stamp duty alone would be in the region of £38 million.

So what does £200 million get you in London these days? A fully furnished, dressed-to-the-nines townhouse, even the extensive art on the walls. And as the final touches are put in place (two men are laying a rich blue runner up the main staircase’s 170 steps, a 104ft drop from top to bottom that’s certainly not a job for vertigo sufferers), Main gives me the inaugural tour. He seems a little frantic and frazzled – which isn’t surprising, given this is the culmination of five intense years of redeveloping a Grade II listed freehold mansion, full of protected features such as every piece of wood, under the exacting eye of Historic England.

That timespan pales, however, when you learn that the interior designer Martin Kemp has been on the project, under various owners, for 18 years. ‘It’s sort of sad that it’s finished,’ says Kemp, who has joined us on the tour. His mind is no doubt whirring as he recalls the hundreds of specialist artisans he has encountered along the way. Or the gargantuan challenge of illuminating this house: as well as 137 wall lights, 80 floor lamps, and large numbers of lamps and picture lights, there are 34 ceiling ‘installations’ – lights that aren’t just lights, but exquisite one-off works of art. In the formal dining room, a 200kg chandelier by the Venetian glassworks Rocco Borghese required 1,736 precision-cut crystal prisms to be hand-assembled on site, then hauled into place by 10 men.

Main, meanwhile, shows off the sultry walk-in humidor (the perfect man cave) and powder rooms decorated with his favourite de Gournay hand-painted silk wall­paper – both inspired by the cheekily decadent décor of the private members’ club Annabel’s – before reflecting that it’s been a ‘super-turbulent’ five years in which to develop a Grade II listed mansion. ‘I’d never do anything like this again,’ he says. ‘Inflation has been running at 10 per cent. There have been tough geo-political tailwinds. We’ve had contractors go bust and a two-year delay. A new build is far less challenging.’

The pressure was on from the start. The previous owner, from whom Main and his long-term investor, CPI Property Group, bought the house in 2019 for £45.25 million, insisted on exchange and completion within five days, after tiring of her own renovation project.

They have since spent many tens of millions of pounds (Main won’t confirm how many, but we can assume it’s exceeded his original estimate of around £50 million) on turning this townhouse, built in the 1670s, and remodelled by the revered English architect Edwin Lutyens in 1911, into a palatial residence that preserves its heritage while providing what uncompromising billionaires want from a home these days.

One prospective buyer explained that he had just 17 minutes to look around as he was in a hurry to get to the state banquet with King Charles and Donald Trump. But you could easily spend a couple of hours exploring every room and still barely touch the surface.

Where prospective buyers emit their most exuberant ‘wows’ as they tour the floors will be down to taste – but there are many. For some, it’ll be the 3,000sq ft basement spa that wins them over, with its long lap pool framed by mosaic-tiled columns, and amenities – gym, sauna, steam room, massage room – that are better than those of most five-star hotels.

Others will be seduced by the Hermès boutique-inspired dressing room, part of the master suite occupying the entire third floor, with joinery by cabinet makers who have worked on Buckingham Palace and the Vatican, Main informs me. There are seven further bedroom suites, ‘like five-star Parisian hotel suites’, he adds, as we gaze at snowy white carpets too perfect to tread on.
Kemp has gone to town on huge ‘his and hers’ bathrooms too – hers, a bright, ornate room with a gleaming brass and glass tardis of a shower (‘it’s a boudoir, the detailing is classical and the result is palatial’); his, a moodily dark sanctuary, with a centrepiece stone bathtub alongside a fireplace, chandelier and disguised TV screen.

Alongside all the opulence, there are rooms that hint that this might be a family home of sorts. The subterranean cinema, for example – where UHNW sprogs will keep themselves entertained, but so will their parents. Main draws back curtains to reveal a picture window that overlooks the 10-car basement garage. ‘I loved Tron when I was young,’ Kemp says of the inspiration behind the electric-blue ribbons of light that weave around the garage floor. ‘It could double up as an amazing nightclub,’ he adds.

The garage is accessed via an unassuming back alley, which you’d never know leads to the house. You can drive your car through two sets of security gates and directly into another of this property’s rare features: the large courtyard garden. Appealing to the likely buyer’s need for privacy, the garden is framed by the entirely windowless walls of neighbouring office buildings.

For some with a couple of hundred million to spend, though, the cachet will lie in having a house that overflows with quintessentially English heritage. ‘If the buyer is a big tech guy from the US, they will have their ultra-modern house in the hills but they want history, sophistication and the highest level of finishes. It’s a trophy,’ says Main. They, then, will love the double-height, oak-panelled library, which will feed fantasies of a Bodleian-style reading room. Much has been restored to how Lutyens envisaged it, including an original clock.

Just as the world has changed since this renovation began, the lifestyles and tastes of the super-rich have shifted too, certainly in the nearly two decades since Kemp came up with the original CGIs. But, much of his original vision remains. The result is opulent, certainly, but not bling. ‘This was about bringing back heritage. Modern dates, but I don’t think this will,’ Kemp says.
‘Timeless’ is a word he often uses. And while there is smart Crestron tech throughout, it can be the simple things that catch the eye of the world’s wealthiest house-hunters – such as simple old-school light switches. ‘Everyone comments on them and says they want them for their house,’ he says, as if they were the wackiest invention ever.

And to complete the picture, whoever lives here will want a full coterie of staff – but in true Upstairs, Downstairs fashion, they will ideally be invisible. For that, Main has designed a ‘skin’ around the living areas – a system of separate corridors, entrances and staff accommodation, so they can come and go without intruding upon the family’s living spaces. There are small back kitchens on every floor, too, so food prepared in the catering kitchen in the basement can be delivered by dumb waiter to every area of the house.

Main is dealing personally with all viewings – and only with the buyer, no intermediaries, ‘to avoid time-wasters’, he says. Agents who have taken a peek in recent months, however, are impressed. ‘I’d put it in the category of “Show me another one”, because you can’t,’ says Stuart Bailey, Knight Frank’s head of super-prime sales. ‘It’s a fabulous address, a wide house with high ceilings, outdoor space and secure parking. It’s what the market is looking for. A statement asset like this puts a flag in the sand – it says, “I’ve arrived, I’m serious.” It’s a collector’s item.’

Becky Fatemi, executive partner at UK Sotheby’s International Realty, is dealing with ‘a roster of billionaires’ looking for a place in London, she says, and this house is ‘really sensational’. She’s had offers on a couple of off-market properties costing around £200 million, she says, ‘so this price isn’t crazy. An asset like this sets its own price because it’s being sold turnkey [so you can move straight in]. You’d never be able to recreate this if you did it yourself, as the cost of work has become prohibitive. And it’s the only one like it.’

As for Main, he is in no hurry to sell. After five years of blood, sweat and tears, he’s happy to admire the finished result for a while, and to use it for events and as a showcase of what he can do. Just don’t ask him to show you another one.

data.title: ‘It’s idyllic’: The jobs that come with their own home
data.description:
With housing costs now the single biggest strain on finances, workers are hunting for a radical solution. And some are finding it through a hidden gem in the employment market – the “tied accommodation” role.

From chefs and gardeners to teachers and animal carers, professionals are increasingly seeking positions that offer refuge from the relentless climb of housing costs.

The figures are stark. The average weekly mortgage payment has soared to £242, according to the Government’s latest English Housing Survey, up from £182 just five years ago. For renters, the outlook is even more grim, with Zoopla reporting average monthly rents of £1,320, outstripping typical mortgage payments.

In this landscape, a job that includes a home is not a mere perk – it’s a life-changing financial reprieve.

‘Job with a house’

Vicki Alford, 47, horse unit manager at Blue Cross rehoming centre in Burford, agrees. For two decades, her role caring for over 60 rescued horses on-site – and overseeing nearly 500 more at properties nationwide – has come with a home.

She started in a flat and later moved to a three-bedroom bungalow with a large garden to accommodate her growing family. Managing a 120-acre site where horses often arrive in desperate need of veterinary and behavioural care is a round-the-clock labour of love. “Every month, around 20 to 30 need retraining,” she explains.

Alford’s need for an on-site house was proven one memorable night when 15 mares foaled simultaneously. “I was the only one on duty, so I helped with the births until the vet arrived,” she says.

Her family has also benefitted from the lifestyle that comes with the job. Alford’s two children grew up surrounded by horses, and freedom from a mortgage or rent has allowed her to save substantially.

While her part-time salary might be modest – the full-time equivalent is paid up to £35,436 – having a cost-free home has paid off. The arrangement has enabled her to save for a house, which she now rents out, securing her financial future.

‘I do pay rent, but it’s subsidised’

It’s a similar story for Louise Ellis, head gardener at English Heritage’s Audley End House and Gardens in Saffron Walden.

“I’ve lived and worked here for 17 years. I started out as a trainee gardener on the minimum wage after a career change from social care and gained my horticultural qualification,” she explains.

Now in charge of 13 paid staff and around 65 volunteers, Ellis oversees the landscaped parkland and the Victorian kitchen garden, which includes a vinery dating back to the 1820s. What she particularly loves about her role is that, while she has climbed to a managerial position, she still does much of the hands-on gardening.

She lives in Orchard Cottage, which is one of the original Victorian staff houses. The one-storey, two-bedroom home has character features including a vaulted ceiling, along with a modern extension containing the bedrooms and a bathroom. Ellis lives alone as her partner is based in Norfolk.

“It’s very well-maintained and sits within the unrestored parts of the walled garden. I also have my own private garden with fruit trees,” she says. Ironically, there is a large, detached red-brick home called the Head Gardener’s House, but that is now let out to paying holiday guests.

There are four staff members who live on site, including the stable manager and other gardeners. “The provision of housing is an allowance for our out-of-hours responsibilities. We must respond quickly if there is an emergency, which requires us to live on site,” she says.

“I do pay rent, but it’s subsidised. It has enabled me to save a quarter of my salary every month, something I’ve been very focused on now that I am 55 and retirement is on the horizon. I’ll need to work until I reach the state pension age, but my job keeps me physically fit, so that’s a benefit,” she says.

She is aware that she lives in an expensive market town, where a two-bedroom home costs on average £1,359 per month. “I wouldn’t be able to live here on my salary if I had to rent privately. I’d probably need to move further out towards Suffolk to afford a similar home,” she says.

“English Heritage is a great landlord. It deals with repairs promptly and is progressive – we have oil central heating, but it is looking at air-source heat pumps and alternative fuel sources,” she says. 

Ellis doesn’t own a property elsewhere and knows that when she retires from Audley End, she will be back to paying for a home in the private rental sector.

‘It’s idyllic’

Hospitality, with its long and sometimes anti-social hours, is another industry that frequently offers staff accommodation – particularly in remotely located hotels.

Billy McKechnie, 45, is general manager of the Royal Marine Hotel in Brora, located an hour’s drive from Inverness along the North Coast 500.

He has been in the role for three and a half years. Part of his daily duties include playing the bagpipes to welcome guests to breakfast. Along with his wife Minette and their three children, he is provided with accommodation.

“Our children play in the hills or at the beach, visit neighbouring castles and play golf in their free time – it’s idyllic,” says McKechnie.

Lifestyle aside, the perk of staff accommodation is a definite help for the family’s purse strings. “The hotel contributes towards the rent on our house, which is £1,200 per month. We chose the house ourselves. It’s five minutes by car from the hotel.”

In an area that is losing residents to nearby cities, providing hotel staff with subsidised housing is a key incentive for securing their commitment.

“We have a house in Inverness that we rent out. We wouldn’t have moved from there if the hotel didn’t provide us with a home,” he says. Plus, if the family had sold their main home to buy closer to McKechnie’s workplace, they would have faced both seller’s fees and stamp duty costs.

For younger workers, having accommodation provided allows them to go where the jobs are.

James Greenwood-Penny, 24, is the sous chef at The Cottage in the Wood in Malvern. “I was born and grew up in Cornwall – a long way from Malvern,” he says.

He notes that without the housing perk, rent alone would have consumed three quarters of his pay – and that’s before bills. By saving his entire salary, he is building up funds for a future down payment on a house – a dream made possible only by having a job that comes with a home.

data.title: ‘I thought I was on the phone to NatWest’s security team – but it was a scammer raiding my account’
data.description:
Mallika Basu was looking forward to a good 2026. The 48-year-old food writer was gearing up for a book launch – her first “actual, proper book”.

It took just a two-hour phone call to bring her hopes for the year crashing down. The mother-of-two from south London was scammed out of more than £5,700.

A couple of days earlier she had received a text which she thought was from her phone company, telling her to claim reward points she was owed. Basu clicked on the link and entered her card details as requested.

Worried she had done the wrong thing, she told NatWest that she thought her card might be compromised.

Then, on Jan 10, she received a strange text. The message asked her to approve a transaction of nearly £400 to eBay, which she knew nothing about. When she declined, she received a phone call.

It was the NatWest fraud team – or so she was told – and her account had been compromised.

“The first question I asked – because I’ve never been scammed in my life – was, ‘How do I know you’re calling from NatWest?’

“They said, ‘We are calling from NatWest, we would never ask for your pin and we would never ask for your password’. So they were mimicking what would normally happen,” she says.

The fraudsters convinced her that her money was unsafe and that it could be syphoned off to Pakistan, where it would be unrecoverable. Then they applied pressure – telling Basu that they couldn’t guarantee the safety of her money.

“They kept putting me on hold and saying, ‘We’re speaking to the security team. Because your account has been compromised online, we need to make sure that they can’t go in and apply for an overdraft or apply for a loan’,” she says.

She tried to move money out of her account – but the real NatWest recognised that she was being coerced quickly and blocked the attempted transactions. The fraudsters changed tack. If one account had been compromised then her other bank accounts could be too.

“Where else do you bank?” they asked.

Basu had personal and business accounts with online bank Starling: “They said: ‘Okay, well, NatWest has bought Starling and we have access. If you’re compromised on NatWest, you’re compromised on Starling too’.”

The food writer hadn’t heard of a takeover but she was convinced to move her money from Starling: “They got me on the basis of that to transfer my money urgently.

“Of course, now looking back, clearly they were following the path of least resistance,” she says.

The fraudsters would tell her whatever she needed to hear to trust them.

In three transactions, Basu moved more than £5,770 from her Starling business account. The first payment, through Western Union, was for £3,500. She was told that the money was going into a new, safe Starling account.

Basu claims that she did not give the fraudsters her Starling bank card details but the scammers were able to trigger card payments on her account, which came up as notifications for approval in her app. It is unclear how the scammers got this information.

“I did not set up the transactions. The transactions were generated. I was sent transactions to approve,” Basu says.

Starling says that Basu was shown 10 fraud warnings during the call, including ones which said that she was not on the phone to the bank. Basu says she has no recollection of the alerts.

She says: “If they’ve sent me in-app warnings, I am already lulled into a state where I am thinking, ‘Oh, it doesn’t matter, they’re protecting me’. So they’re essentially neutralising these warnings. I just don’t think it’s a very effective safeguard.”

Fraud has been rising, fuelled by AI and fake social media adverts with politicians, police forces and City regulators at a loss for how to tackle it. Britons lost more than £1bn to scams every year between 2020 and 2024, according to UK Finance. Another £630m was lost in the first half of last year.

Breaking the spell created by the emotional manipulation at the core of the scammers’ playbook is very difficult.

A three-year national fraud strategy – spearheaded by Lord Hanson of Flint, the fraud minister – is set to be published by the Home Office this spring. It comes after the launch of Report Fraud, which replaced the much-maligned Action Fraud.

Since October 2024, victims of authorised push payment (APP) fraud have been due reimbursement from their bank under a mandatory scheme overseen by the Payment Systems Regulator (PSR).

The latest figures showed that £173m was paid out by banks in the first year that the rules applied – or 83pc of the reported losses.

David Geale, the head of the PSR, told MPs at a Treasury select committee hearing earlier this month that the rules had been a “huge incentive” for banks to improve their fraud controls.

But the transactions that Basu had approved on her Starling app were card payments. This meant that she was not covered by the mandatory reimbursement rules, which only apply to Faster Payments or CHAPS – so, she has been left £3,500 out of pocket.

In letters seen by the Telegraph in response to her complaint, Starling said that it could have done more to stop the later transactions made by Basu, including another £2,160 which was sent just seven minutes later. It refunded around 40pc of the money she lost.

Basu questioned why Starling allowed any of the payments through at all, especially when NatWest had not.

The food writer says she was under a lot of stress because she was about to launch her book, In Good Taste. The scam emptied her business account.

She explains: “I was due to launch my first book which wasn’t a cookbook – the first time I’ve written an actual, proper book – in a week’s time. It was high stress.

“The pressure was immense and I was terrified that all my money would go [as the scammers told her].

“Of course it did. They got me. They took absolutely everything, I was left penniless basically.”

A spokesman for Starling said: “We understand how devastating this must be for the customer. Scams are a scourge and we make every effort to protect our customers from them.

“The customer was provided with 10 different warnings by our systems over the course of her transactions with the scammer. Six of these warnings required acknowledgement, which the customer gave before proceeding with the transactions.

“In this case, our transaction controls should have automatically blocked the second payment, even though the customer acknowledged the scam risks and wanted to proceed.

“While this scam is not covered by the PSR’s mandatory reimbursement rules, we have refunded the customer the second payment of £2,160 to Western Union as an acknowledgement that this payment could have been blocked by our systems.”

A spokesman for NatWest said: “We are glad we have been able to prevent Ms Basu from having her money stolen through a bank impersonation scam. At NatWest, we are using the latest tools and technology to catch and detect scams.

“We will never ask any customer to move money from their account to another account ‘to keep it safe’; this is one of the most common signs of a scam.”

data.title: Reeves accused of putting vital South West rail route at risk
data.description:
Rachel Reeves has been accused of putting South West England’s main rail route at risk by limiting maintenance spending while promising billions for Northern projects.

Fears are mounting that a sea cliff could collapse on to the line in Devon, cutting off Plymouth and the whole of Cornwall, after recent storms saw a sinkhole near the railway in Dawlish.

The cliff in question had been earmarked for £400m of earthworks after a 2014 collapse closed the line for eight weeks, costing the local economy £1.2bn.

However, the plan was abandoned after Labour sought to cut costs across the UK’s rail network. Instead, ministers suggested the cliff would be monitored for signs of movement. 

Storm Ingrid, which battered Devon two weeks ago, also saw waves destroy sections of a sea wall protecting the tracks at Dawlish, closing the line for two days.

Rebecca Smith, Tory MP for South West Devon, said the damage had stoked concerns that spending cuts had left the lifeline route exposed to potential disaster.

She said: “With all the tightening of the budget by the Chancellor, she has taken away contingency funding. So if there were something that needed an emergency reaction, the implication is that the money isn’t actually there.

“If you get the right kind of freakish storm, who knows what could happen. The question for me is, should this not be something that is in capital funding on a year-on-year basis?”

After Ms Smith asked in the Commons whether funding could be guaranteed for unplanned resilience work, James Murray, the chief secretary to the Treasury, said that budgets allow ministers to respond to emergencies.

He said: “All individual departments must recognise that unexpected pressures will come along; they need to prepare for them and make sure they have robust plans to respond.”

Ms Smith, a member of the transport select committee, said the Government’s reluctance to fund work on the cliff stood in contrast to its backing for the £45bn Northern Powerhouse Rail project, for which Ms Reeves last month announced £1bn of preparatory funding.

She said: “Why do they want to take a gamble when they are investing billions in other parts of the country? Why do we need a marginally faster rail system in the North when in the Southwest, if this went again, we’d be cut off for, I don’t know how long?”

Ms Smith also raised doubts about the level of monitoring that Network Rail is carrying out on the cliff, which is protected by the railway from the sea but prone to becoming sodden with surface water.

She said: “Are they monitoring it or just draining things? We need answers if they are not prepared to put the investment in to fix it.”

Martin Wrigley, Liberal Democrat MP for Newton Abbot, which includes Dawlish, said that had Storm Ingrid hit when seas were higher, the damage could have been much more severe.

He said the Department for Transport (DfT) should grant Network Rail money to undertake a study into a long-term solution for the cliff.

He said: “Monitoring is no good because the last collapse was a single, catastrophic failure, almost a tectonic shift of part of the cliff which came down on to the railway.”

Mr Wrigley said the damage to the Dawlish sea wall was also concerning, having affected areas on either side of a new section installed after the 2014 collapse.

The DfT said work carried out after the 2014 events held up well in the recent storms, with damage limited to a low wall between the coastal path and the railway. 

It said funding had been provided for a drainage trial and a range of advanced monitoring equipment, including tilt sensors that would provide a quick response if triggered.

Work will continue with Network Rail to assess the investment needed to ensure the line’s resilience and to develop any longer-term solutions.

data.title: Killer motorists should be treated like the murderers they are
data.description:
April 25 2007 is etched forever in my mind. It was a beautiful day, and summer was just around the corner. My twin sister had given birth to a baby boy, and my 65-year-old mother, Elizabeth, had come to stay with me in Mortlake, south London. We planned to go to the Chelsea and Westminster Hospital to visit the new baby.

My husband walked my two eldest children, Barnaby and Sapphire – who were six and four at the time – to school and then hopped on a train to work. My mother, my two-year-old daughter, Pollyanna, and I set off to catch the bus to the hospital.

My mother, who lived in rural Shropshire, loved London buses and much preferred them to the train.

We walked, with Pollyanna in her pram, the short distance from our house to the local bus depot. As we approached, Pollyanna climbed out of her buggy and held my mother’s hand.

This was when my life changed irreversibly. I turned around, and all I could see was a monstrous, red Metroline bus approaching at a ferocious speed. Instead of turning into the depot, it drove on to the pavement, aiming straight for us. It happened so fast – almost like a bomb going off.

My legs were trapped under the bus, and I was like the jam in the middle of a horrid sandwich – bus, me, wall. Blood was everywhere. I slipped in and out of consciousness. Out of one eye, I saw my darling, precious, beautiful mother slipping away. She did not survive.

Out of my other eye, I saw my little daughter about 20 ft away. She had been flung through the air, and her right leg was hanging off. I was trapped and could not help her. I shouted for my mother so loudly. I wanted her to answer me, but she did not. She could not.

The crash quickly flooded the news as my husband – The Telegraph’s Christopher Hope – received a call at work to tell him what had happened.

As he made the terrible journey from his office in Victoria to Mortlake, he did not even know if we were alive or not. Four surgeons spent seven hours trying to save Pollyanna’s leg, but they could not, and she had it amputated.

I suffered severe degloving in my leg (where skin and soft tissue is torn from the muscle or bone underneath), among other injuries. However, knowing that I would never see my mother again was the most unbearable wound.

The bus driver who hit us was found guilty of one count of death by dangerous driving and two counts of grievous bodily harm. He was sentenced to four years in prison, which is simply not long enough. Often, only aggravating factors like being under the influence of drink or drugs result in a longer sentence, but it is rare that criminal drivers get more than 12 years behind bars.

On average, four people die every day on UK roads, and many dozens more suffer life-changing injuries. It is no wonder that victims of road crime – like me – feel utterly let down by the UK’s criminal justice system.

Metroline would not speak to me when I rang up their head office. I felt upset, hopeless and angry. So, in February 2014, I set out on a mission – for road crime to be treated as real crime, and for victims and their families to be treated with kindness and compassion in navigating the criminal justice system.

I met Boris Johnson, who was the mayor of London at the time. He said he was very sorry for what had happened to my family. He asked me whether Transport for London (TfL) had apologised, and I said no.

He told me that must change. A few weeks later, my husband and I met with TfL and Metroline. They said they were very sorry. I said that “sorry” must hold meaning, and things began to change from then on.

The Sarah Hope Line was launched in February 2016. It is an incident line that offers confidential support to people involved in, or affected by, life-changing incidents on the TfL network. We have provided to more than 500 families what TfL did not give to us: trauma counselling, assistance with funeral costs and arrangements, and short-term accommodation for family members. Next Monday will mark our 10-year anniversary.

While the line supports families of the bereaved, we still have not yet changed the attitude within government that road crashes are “just one of those things”. This Government should spend much more on policing our roads, so that criminal drivers can be caught. We need to issue immediate fines and driving bans so motorists are deterred from driving dangerously.

Road crime and the damage it causes cost the taxpayer billions of pounds every year – it strains the NHS, criminal justice system and our emergency services. Fatalities, alone, cost the NHS billions every year. That money should be spent on policing our roads and preventing such devastation.

Perpetrators think they can get away with causing death by dangerous driving because sentences do not reflect the severity of the crime. Change must start now. We must no longer be the forgotten victims.

The Sarah Hope Line is on 0343 222 5678, Monday to Friday, 8am-6pm. For more details, go to https://tfl.gov.uk/travel-information/safety/incident-support-service

data.title: Heathrow boss: Airport isn’t crowded... foreigners just walk the wrong way
data.description:
The chief executive of Heathrow has said the airport is not crowded because foreigners just walk the wrong way.

Thomas Woldbye said people complain the airport is too busy when in fact people are just “crashing into each other”.

This is because European travellers are used to walking on the right, while the British walk on the left.

Mr Woldbye told an Aviation Club UK event on Thursday: “One of the reasons people think [Terminal 5] is crowded – it’s not, actually. But yes, people are in the wrong place.

“Problem is that all the British people keep to the left and normally Europeans keep to the right. And they do that in both directions. So we can be crashing into each other and I see that from personal experience.

“We just [need to] make sure that everybody going this way keeps going left, and [those] going this way keep to the right,” he added, gesturing with his hands to illustrate the different directions.

The humorous aside came after the Danish-born airport boss warned earlier this week that Heathrow could lose its coveted spot as Europe’s busiest airport to rivals such as Amsterdam or Paris unless a third runway is approved for construction.

Mr Woldbye said on Tuesday: “We remain Europe’s largest airport but latest figures show we may lose that position in 2026 and we cannot keep driving growth for the UK economy without more capacity.”

When asked what he thought of the Government’s position on the third runway, he said it was broadly supportive. But he added: “We don’t have long-term regulation, which is clear in terms of us building a business case.”

Last year, Heidi Alexander, the Transport Secretary, gave the go-ahead to Heathrow’s preferred plan to build a third runway over the top of the M25 motorway, a scheme likely to generate controversy over its cost and complexity.

The third runway scheme, which will see a 3,500-metre strip built to the north-west of Heathrow’s existing site, is currently estimated to cost around £49bn.

Included in the controversial plans are a scheme to build a 66,000-space car park at a cost of £2.6bn, as revealed by the City AM financial newspaper last summer.

The airport boss was also criticised on Thursday for raising drop-off fees paid by drivers to £7 – and threatening an £80 fine for motorists spending longer than 10 minutes saying goodbye to their loved ones.

He said in response to the criticism: “So when we make profits on all parts of the business, rather than just running the airport, that actually goes to reducing the charge [applied to passengers’ tickets].

“Whenever we make less money ... passengers are actually paying [for] that,” he added.

“We have an incentive to make as much money as we can, on the side, from anything that actually reduces the charge for passengers.”

Heathrow’s charges are regulated by the Government. The airport pays for its infrastructure by imposing a charge on airline passengers’ tickets.

Airlines, including Virgin Atlantic and British Airways, have set up a pressure group called Heathrow Reimagined, which calls for “urgent and fundamental reform” of this funding system.

data.title: US is best place to invest, says boss of British drugs giant
data.description:
The boss of Britain’s largest drug developer has praised the US as the best place to invest amid fears over the waning appeal of the UK.

Dame Emma Walmsley, the outgoing chief executive of GlaxoSmithKline (GSK), said it was delusional to suggest Britain could become a competitor to the US. She lauded America as key to the group’s future growth.

“It’s more than half of GSK’s global turnover today,” she said of the US. “It’s still the leading market in the world in terms of the launches of new drugs and vaccines. It’s still, probably alongside China … the best market in the world to do business development.

“No one should be deluded that the UK is going to be a massive scale market, a domestic market, but it can be an exporter of innovation in life sciences.”

Dame Emma said GSK, which spends £1bn developing new drugs in the UK every year, is preparing to invest $30bn (£23bn) in the US by the end of this decade.

She is set to leave GSK at the end of the year after eight years in charge.

‘Worst country in Europe’ for drug prices

Her comments are likely to fuel fears about the attractiveness of Britain’s pharma sector after several major drugmakers cancelled UK projects worth billions – amid concerns over NHS drug price rules and pressure from Donald Trump, the US president.

AstraZeneca recently announced it was pausing a planned £200m investment in a Cambridge research facility, while Merck scrapped plans for a £1bn research centre in London and laid off 125 scientists.

In September, Eli Lilly, the American manufacturer of weight loss drug Mounjaro, also said that it was reconsidering plans for Gateway Labs, its London-based hub that provides support for biotech startups.

The UK Government has struggled to revive overseas interest in Britain in recent years, with the number of foreign direct investment projects falling 12pc last year to a record low of 1,375, according to official figures.

High energy costs, recent pressures like the increase in employers’ National Insurance contributions and wider geopolitical uncertainty have all been cited as reasons for declining investment in the UK.

One of the key concerns of Britain’s pharmaceuticals industry has been over NHS drug pricing in the UK. 

After postponing its investment, Dave Ricks, the chief executive of Eli Lilly, said the UK was “probably the worst country in Europe” for drug prices.

The Government agreed to a deal with the US at the start of the month to scrap tariffs on UK drug shipments – in a bid to end the row with Britain’s pharmaceutical industry. 

Dame Emma welcomed the deal as “a step in the right direction” for Britain.

The agreement means the UK will pay more for medicines through the NHS, in return for a guarantee that US import taxes on pharmaceuticals made in Britain will remain at zero for three years.

data.title: ‘What does the RSC really need? A better train line to Stratford’
data.description:
I meet Daniel Evans and Tamara Harvey on the morning they announce their biggest coup to date – bringing Game of Thrones to the Stratford main stage this summer. The Mad King, a prequel play to the epic fantasy saga, has been written with the blessing and input of author George RR Martin. The news coincides, oddly, with the dramatic arrest of Andrew Mountbatten-Windsor (“Very Westeros,” Evans quips).

Have the two artistic directors of the Royal Shakespeare Company hit on the holy grail – the next Stranger Things: First Shadow, perhaps or Harry Potter and the Cursed Child? “That thinking is dangerous,” Evans, 52, counters. “The minute you think like that, you can jinx it.

“The reason we’re passionate about this is because it reads like a Shakespeare history play. It concerns leadership, succession, power, internecine fighting. George RR Martin is obsessed with Shakespeare.”

The globally successful HBO series (2011-19) was notorious for its scenes of sex and violence – it carried an 18 certificate in Britain. The prequel centres on the fabled Great Tourney [jousting tournament] at Harrenhal castle, and the tyrant king Aerys II Targaryen. “It’s going to be total theatre,” promises Evans of the production, which will be directed by Dominic Cooke (Hello, Dolly!). “There will be a content advisory, but we’re expecting it to be something the whole family can enjoy.”

The pair also tell me about the next wave of RSC programming for the autumn and winter which is announced today. This includes an all-male production of As You Like It (directed by Evans), Harriet Walter reprising her star turn as Brutus in a 90-minute version of Phyllida Lloyd’s acclaimed all-female Julius Caesar, plus a two-part adaptation of Middlemarch from Nina Raine. The year looks set to end on a swashbuckling high with The Three Musketeers, in which Dumas’s musketeers will be – gasp! – female.

Evans and Harvey, are a seamless and courteous double act. Having both enjoyed success running regional theatres (him: Sheffield and Chichester; her: Theatr Clwyd in Wales), they bonded during the stresses of the pandemic, and applied for one of the biggest jobs in British theatre on a joint ticket in 2022, succeeding Erica Whyman, who was briefly promoted from deputy after 10 years of Gregory Doran at the helm. Their tenure began properly in 2024. It’s full-on stuff, with Harvey, 48, talking about days that run from dawn to midnight, with her family commitments as a mother of two interspersed: “We often wish we could clone ourselves.”

In a departure from longstanding RSC man Doran’s methodical march through the canon, they have modified the approach so that it’s now more about bringing in diverse artistic talents with fresh, exciting ideas about what to stage, and how to stage it. As Harvey explains: “For us, there’s no point in putting on King John just because it hasn’t been done for a few years.”

The new rule is that there is no rule – anything could, conceivably, be an RSC show. While that approach might alarm traditionalists, it has reaped dividends in terms of ticket sales. More than 352,000 people attended productions in Stratford in their first year and The BFG last Christmas was the highest-grossing play in the history of the RSC. Rupert Goold’s Hamlet also played to 90 per cent capacity, while Kenneth Branagh’s imminent return to the RSC for the first time in more than 30 years in The Tempest has already sold out, just as Macbeth, starring Outlander’s Sam Heughan, did. Cyrano de Bergerac, starring Adrian Lester, is transferring to the West End this summer on the back of rave reviews.

A recent hit, Measure for Measure at Stratford, played fast and loose with the text – what do they think is acceptable in terms of tweaking texts many regard as sacrosanct? Evans tells me: “It’s OK to rewrite Shakespeare, but it’s not a free-for-all. Give us your rationale. The rule is that we’re not opposed to it. We’re not purists.” Harvey chips in with thoughts fresh from her rehearsals on Henry V, which she is about to bring to the Stratford main stage, with Alfred Enoch in the lead. “You can pick up any Arden edition and the footnotes read like a food fight between different editors,” she says. In her staging, too, she’s feminising some parts: “I didn’t want it to be a world where we assumed that almost everyone is male other than Katharine and Queen Isabel.”

One could easily spend an hour talking about Henry V (Harvey is, shockingly, the first woman to direct the play in the RSC’s history), but there are other serious matters to discuss.

Earlier this month, Trevor Nunn, the former RSC chief, stated that the RSC needed a London home; its purpose-built abode, the Barbican, is now one of a number of venues taking RSC work. “We are working out what London means for us,” says Harvey.

The more pressing task is transport to Stratford, which can seem Elizabethan in its remoteness. “To be frank,” Evans says, “a direct and better train service from London would be transformational. There used to be a direct train to Stratford [until 2023]. There no longer is. And we suffer because of it. When you look at theatre programmes from the 1960s, they used to have the last train time.” Could transport failure scupper their mission? “It might, because if we can’t get people to Stratford, how on earth are we meant to put on plays?”

That sounds quite existential, and behind the upbeat news there are clearly pressing challenges. Dividends reaped from ticket sales have not been substantial enough to mitigate the financial strain on the organisation, which is looking to reduce its workforce to achieve annual savings of £2.8m. In the autumn, the RSC announced that 420 of its 835 employees were eligible for voluntary redundancy – that consultation period is almost complete. The accounts for 2024-25 highlight the deficit problem: total income was £82m, substantially down on the previous year, with total expenditure running over £84m. Since then, annual repayments of the £20m Culture Recovery Fund loan taken out during Covid have kicked in, too. The drop in income partly reflects previous bumper takings at the box office – the 2022 Matilda film helped boost audiences for the stage show. But a cluster of factors are making life tougher.

“If you talk to most theatre leaders up and down the country, this is the case for them too,” Evans says. “Audiences have less money to spend because of the cost of living crisis. Costs have gone up exponentially. And there has long been a stand-still in Arts Council funding [currently approx £15m], which means a real-terms cut.”

There are no magic wands. Shows such as Les Misérables – which bankrolled the RSC for decades – are, he says, “like gold-dust – you’d be a fool to rely on them and part of the work we’re doing [in cutting back expenditure] is insulating the RSC from that reliance”. The desirability of any given corporate sponsor aside (and the RSC withdrew from a BP sponsorship deal in 2019 following protests), those options have dwindled, too: “There’s less money. Wherever the money comes from, there’s a deeper issue about relying on corporate sponsorship now.”

One option would be to scale back on productions, but that isn’t in their game plan, Harvey argues. “We have to find different ways of working but a sure-fire way to oblivion would be to reduce our artistic ambition and do less because then there’d be no point in our existing. You can cut back or you can be ever more ambitious and find different ways of making work and we’re going that route.”

There have been rumblings of discontent, particularly over plans to close the music department, with its in-house musicians. An online petition – attracting almost 7,000 signatures – has called for a rethink. If enough people complain, will they change their position? Harvey is swift to justify the proposed changes: “It’s about ensuring that music is more fully integrated into how we make work and giving composers the opportunity to work with freelance musicians. Some music will be created electronically, some will be recorded, some of it will be live.”

Upheavals notwithstanding, they’re looking to the future, with Evans (also an actor who left drama school early in order to join the RSC in the 1990s), hinting at repertory ensemble models. “We want to keep surprising audiences,” says Harvey.

As the actors bound back into the spacious Ashcroft room to resume rehearsals for Henry V, she leaves me with a final thought. Whenever the weight of responsibility presses hard, she confides, “I love to remember that this place exists because in the 1870s a local brewer and his son thought there should be a theatre in Stratford. The town and the theatre industry told them that they were mad but they understood that these plays survive because they’re performed. I love to remember that right at the root of this is a local brewer who had a radical idea, and the passion to see it through.”

Priority booking for all newly announced productions opens March 2 at 10am, with public booking opening March 18 at 10am. Priority booking for Game of Thrones: The Mad King opens April 14 with public booking from April 24. Info: rsc.org.uk

data.title: Advertising giant WPP to cut £500m in costs as it races to counter AI threat
data.description:
WPP plans to cut £500m in costs as the rise of AI threatens to upend the role of traditional agencies.

The London-listed media group said it aimed to achieve the savings target by 2028 by selling some of its businesses and consolidating its sprawling operations into four key pillars.

The savings will be reinvested in high-growth areas such as AI. The company previously said it would invest around £300m each year in WPP Open, an AI marketing tool that allows clients to create their own campaigns.

WPP and its rivals face an serious threat from the rise of the new technology, which could allow clients to sidestep traditional media companies altogether.

A number of high-profile brands including Coca-Cola and Heinz have already incorporated AI into their campaigns.

The technology still has the potential to misfire. Gucci has come under fire for using AI to generate images promoting its Milan Fashion Week show, with critics dismissing the results as “slop”.

However, the rapidly improving technology poses a significant threat and major advertising groups are scrambling to adapt to the new technology.

As part of the restructuring, WPP will restructure hundreds of ad agencies into four units: creative, media, production and the newly formed enterprise solutions.

WPP, which owns agencies including Ogilvy and Grey, did not say what impact the overhaul would have on staff numbers. The company has already been reducing headcount, with employee numbers dropping by almost 10,000 last year to 98,655.

Cindy Rose, the former Microsoft executive who became chief executive at WPP in September, is seeking to turn the advertising group around after a difficult period of declining sales and major client losses.

WPP’s shares have slumped 65pc in the last year to their lowest level since 1998, while the company has lost its crown as the world’s largest advertising company by revenue to French rival Publicis.

Ms Rose said WPP was an “extraordinary company” but admitted its performance was “just not where it needs to be”.

She added: “Our recent underperformance has been driven by excessive organisational complexity, a lack of an integrated operating model and inconsistent strategic execution.

“While disappointing, I see huge potential as these issues are all within our power to fix and we’re already making great progress.”

WPP’s revenue excluding pass-through costs fell by 5.4pc last year to £11.4bn, with headline operating profit falling by more than a fifth to £1.3bn.

Ms Rose hailed an improvement in winning new business but said revenue will continue to shrink in the first half of this year.

The simplification plans echo the strategy pursued by Ms Rose’s predecessor, Mark Read, who oversaw a major slimming down of the holding group’s network of agencies as it adapted to the growth of digital advertising rivals such as Facebook and Google.

data.title: Police fail to respond to two thirds of shoplifting crimes
data.description:
Police have failed to respond to two thirds of violent or abusive attacks reported in high street stores, despite a pledge to crack down on retail crime.

Officers responded to just 31pc of incidents of abuse, threats and physical violence on the high street reported to them in the year to Aug 31, the British Retail Consortium (BRC) said.

The figures suggest a fraction of attacks in shops are being attended by police, since in the majority of cases retail workers are not reporting crimes to their local officers.

Just 15pc of the 590,000 incidents of abuse, threats and physical violence in high street stores during the period were reported to police, according to the BRC crime survey. The prior year, 32pc of incidents of violence and abuse were reported to police.

The BRC said the decline was driven by changes in how retailers were reporting crimes. High street giants including Tesco and John Lewis, for example, have been part of a programme where they share CCTV and incident reports with police to identify gangs in their stores. Other retailers have bulked up their own security teams.

Attendance by officers to reports was higher than the prior year, when police responded to 10pc of reported incidents of retail violence and abuse. But the BRC said it still remained too low at 31pc.

It said the current “lack of attendance” of police when they were called by shop workers could “discourage reporting and embolden offenders”.

The BRC said: “Police should attend all reported retail crime incidents, particularly those involving violence or where a suspect is being detained.”

Yvette Cooper deployed extra officers on the streets of 500 towns last summer to crack down on shoplifting and anti-social behaviour by “thugs and thieves”. It comes as part of a clampdown by the Government on retail crime, with new laws coming in that will make it a specific offence to assault shop workers.

The head of Britain’s biggest police force recently said officers had stepped up to demands from retailers to help them curb crime.

Speaking to The Telegraph in December, Sir Mark Rowley, the Met commissioner, said forces had responded to demands from retail chiefs for police to do more to tackle rocketing crime levels.

He said the Met was “making a lot of progress” and that the retail sector “need to do better”, such as providing CCTV footage in more case.

Many high street stores have been spending heavily on technology to tackle crime, including installing new cameras and exit gates to stop attacks.

Retailers, including Sainsbury’s and Sports Direct, have deployed facial recognition cameras that alert staff when known shoplifters have entered their stores.

Shop staff faced 118 incidents of physical violence every day in the year to Aug 31, according to the BRC.

It meant there were a total of 43,000 physically violent attacks across the high street last year, slightly down on the previous year’s 45,000. A weapon was involved in 13,000 of the attacks.

data.title: Why chocolate is kept under lock and key in supermarkets
data.description:
First razors had to be taken to the till, then shampoo had to be unlocked by a shop worker.

Now, Dairy Milk and Lindt chocolate bars are being secured behind screens and locked into anti-theft boxes.

Supermarkets, including Sainsbury’s and Tesco, are facing a growing tide of chocolate thefts, which retailers and police say is a result of “organised gangs” and a growing resale market, especially with Easter approaching.

“They used to take the washing powders, then we introduced the screen, so they went for the dishwasher tablets,” said one manager at a Sainsbury’s branch in central London, who wished to remain anonymous. 

“Now, with the chocolate, they’ll probably just move on to something else.”

Her fatigue was echoed by a manager at a Tesco store nearby, who said chocolate had become “the next easiest thing” to steal.

She added: “If a customer can’t get a particular item because there are these protections, they’ll find something else.”

Supermarkets and retailers have been forced to counter increasingly brazen thieves, with the Sainsbury’s manager describing shoplifters with “big bags” who sweep “everything from the shelf”.

The Heart of England Co-op Group told The Telegraph that chocolate was its most stolen product in 2024. 

In 2025, it became second only to alcohol, costing the group £250,000 over the past year.

In Sainsbury’s stores, chocolate is now placed behind sliding screens or locked in boxes, with the London store manager explaining that some of the more expensive chocolates, such as Lindt Excellence, are limited to only three on display at a time.

In Tesco, the same Lindt chocolate bars, which retail for just £3.85, are displayed in security-protected boxes.

Overall, shoplifting is costing the retail industry an estimated £400m a year, with more than five million incidents annually.

The British Retail Consortium has warned that the nature of “high value” is shifting, as everyday commodities such as chocolate, coffee, fish and olive oil increasingly become priority targets for thieves.

Lucy Whing, crime policy adviser for the BRC, said: “On one level, there is the fact that these items are smaller and therefore easier to conceal. But they’ve also become new avenues for organised gangs to sell on market stalls or in unscrupulous pubs or restaurants.”

Chocolate lock-boxes, security tags and sliding screens are the more visible measures being put in place in stores across the country in retailers’ efforts to ramp up their prevention of crime.

Behind the scenes, extensive training of staff, including resources on how to handle situations including theft and harassment, are rolled out to train workers for an environment increasingly riddled with risk.

Shoplifting incidents including violence and abuse also remain rife. 

Despite falling by a fifth from the previous year to 1,600 incidents per day in 2025, Ms Whing noted that the figure remains “concerningly high” as it is still far higher than the pre-pandemic rate of 455 per day.

For independent shopkeepers, such as Abhishek Chemban, 26, who is often single-handedly running a corner store in the heart of a bustling Piccadilly Circus, the threat from shoplifting carries all the same pressures with little of the protections on offer at larger retailers.

“We experience two or three shoplifting incidents every weekend, with people stealing up to £15,” Mr Chemban said, adding that his shop “wouldn’t be able to afford to put in place the protections that they have. The best we can do is have another member of staff working”.

While organised gang members account for a significant proportion of theft crimes, shop workers said that they regularly experienced people who appeared inconspicuous walking out with unpaid-for products.

Mr Chemban recounted a recent occasion when a woman entered the shop with her baby and began pulling items off the shelves, claiming they belonged to her baby when he confronted her.

The BRC hopes that new government legislation to remove the £200 threshold for “low level” theft will send a “strong message to offenders”, with Ms Whing adding that it would: “indicate that no matter what kind, theft will not be tolerated.

Ms Whing said that the new security systems that separate customers from their shopping are likely to become the new norm as retailers ramp up their efforts to reduce losses.

“Hopefully, if we carry on in that direction then there can be a transition back. But it’s hard to know at the moment when the numbers are still so high.”

data.title: Paramount raises bid for Warner Bros in attempt to block Netflix takeover
data.description:
Warner Bros has confirmed it has received an increased takeover bid from Larry Ellison’s Paramount, but suggested it was still in favour of a rival $83bn deal with Netflix.

The Hollywood studio said it was reviewing a revised offer from Paramount on Monday and would update shareholders once the review is complete.

But the company added: “The Netflix merger agreement remains in effect, and the board continues to recommend in favour of the Netflix transaction.”

Warner Bros did not confirm the details of the new Paramount offer. The Los Angeles-headquartered company had previously offered $30 per share, valuing Warner Bros at $108.4bn (£80.3bn).

The improved bid represents a late effort by Paramount to derail an $83bn takeover agreed between Warner Bros and Netflix last year.

The board of Warner Bros has repeatedly rebuffed Paramount’s advances, insisting that the Netflix deal offers superior value. A shareholder vote on the deal is scheduled for March 20.

But the company, which is behind major film franchises including the Harry Potter series, had agreed to give Paramount a week to submit its best offer or walk away.

Heated bidding war

Under the terms of its takeover deal, Netflix has the right to match any improved rival offer, raising the prospect of a heated bidding war.

Netflix has agreed to pay $27.75 per share for Warner Bros’s studio business and the HBO Max streaming service. By contrast, Paramount’s offer also includes the group’s traditional cable channels, including the CNN news network.

Paramount has previously sweetened its bid by offering to pay a so-called “ticking fee” of $0.25 per share to investors every quarter should its deal fail to close by the end of the year.

It also agreed to cover the $2.8bn termination fee Warner Bros would have to pay Netflix if it abandons their agreed deal, as well as $1.5bn in fees linked to Warner Bros’ debt refinancing.

The rival suitors have been locked in an escalating war of words, with Paramount seeking to highlight the regulatory uncertainty surrounding the Netflix takeover.

The US department of justice (DOJ) has launched a review into the deal amid concerns that combining two major streaming services – Netflix and HBO Max – would hand the company too much power.

Netflix has shrugged off concerns, saying the deal would lead to lower overall streaming costs for consumers. However, it has acknowledged that the regulatory process could take up to 18 months.

Paramount, which would also face regulatory scrutiny, last week said it had cleared a key hurdle with the DOJ.

Netflix has also faced criticism from the cinema industry amid fears the streaming giant could release fewer films on the big screen. James Cameron, the director of Avatar and Titanic, branded the deal “disastrous” in a letter this month.

Netflix has insisted it is committed to theatrical releases while Ted Sarandos, the co-chief executive, branded Mr Cameron’s comments “disingenuous”.

Foreign state ownership

Meanwhile, Mr Sarandos has hit out at Paramount over significant levels of Middle Eastern funding in its bid and claimed that foreign state ownership of media companies is a “bad idea”.

The Netflix chief criticised the involvement of Saudi Arabia, the United Arab Emirates and Qatar in Paramount’s bid, highlighting restrictions on free speech in the Gulf states.

Speaking to the BBC, he said: “I think it’s a bad idea typically to have several sovereign wealth funds in that Paramount deal. Again, a part of the world that is not very big on the First Amendment.”

The sovereign wealth funds of the three Gulf states are contributing $24bn to Paramount’s bid – twice the amount committed by the Ellison family. RedBird Capital, the US private equity fund that was the minority partner in a failed takeover bid for the Telegraph, is also funding the bid.

Paramount has insisted that the sovereign wealth funds will forgo any governance rights, including board seats.

But Mr Sarandos dismissed claims that the Middle Eastern states would have no influence over editorial output.

He said: “It seems very odd to me with the level of investment that we’re talking about that they’d have no influence or editorial control over media in another country.

Alongside regulatory concerns, both Netflix and Paramount must also contend with Donald Trump’s interventions in the deal.

The US president this week called on Netflix to sack Susan Rice, formerly a senior official in Barack Obama’s administration, from its board or “pay the consequences”.

Mr Sarandos played down concerns about political interference, saying: “This is a business deal, it’s not a political deal.”
