data.title: Britain in danger of outsourcing its intellect, warns AI pioneer
data.description:
The artificial intelligence revolution threatens to erode Britain’s sovereignty, one of the country’s most experienced tech entrepreneurs has warned.

Ken Mulvany, co-founder and executive chairman of Benevolent AI, which has pioneered artificial intelligence in drug discovery, told The Telegraph that the United States and China are increasingly dominant in the crucial field.

He says: “If you look at this from the UK or Europe’s perspective, the risk is that these – China and America – are now the two cognitive powers. They’re the ones that are investing the most into this.

“I do worry about having the nation’s intellect effectively outsourced. It’s not just that, either. It’s the productivity gains.

“If for every hour of cognitive work that you do there’s a machine doing what would take you 50 hours, how do you as a nation compete with that?

“Electricity multiplied the power of muscles and AI can do the same with brains in certain scenarios. But it’s almost like you, as Britain and Europe are outsourcing national IQ to US and Chinese tech companies.

“So you’re left trying to regulate something you don’t own. And I do worry about that. I think of it as cognitive border control.”

Mulvany is better placed than most to sound the alarm. An eerily youthful 57 who betrays his Hawaiian roots with a surf-ready hairdo, he is an entrepreneur who has seen tech boom and bust more than once.

In a world increasingly haunted by visions of an AI apocalypse that would make the dotcom crash look like a minor market setback, Mulvany and Benevolent have already been tested to near-destruction.

The technology excited investors – including the star fund manager Neil Woodford long before his self-inflicted implosion – enough to snag a £1.5bn valuation way back in 2018.

This was long before the likes of Sam Altman of OpenAI and Dario Amodei of Anthropic emerged to seek thrones as the next generation of tech plutocrats.

Benevolent sought to help researchers to quickly design new drugs with computer assistance, using machine learning techniques to scour a treasure trove of science information for possibilities at an unprecedented clip. Expansion into defence and energy markets promised new horizons and riches.

It seemed to work. Benevolent burst onto the public markets long before the current AI frontrunners had attracted the attention of everyday investors, too. With the world still in the grip of the pandemic and having discovered an anti-inflammatory that was proving useful on pandemic wards, the start-up made a splashy debut.

“I wasn’t really part of it at that time,” Mulvany recalls ruefully. Having seemingly set up Benevolent for enormous success, he was already easing into semi-retirement.

As it secured a lucrative listing in Amsterdam, Benevolent won endorsement and investment from some of the pharmaceutical industry’s biggest names. AstraZeneca backed Benevolent as part of a transaction that raised hundreds of millions.

Alas, Mulvany’s big payday and exit did not set the scene for a sustainable company. A starry board and big executive hires steered Benevolent off a cliff.

The company lost almost all its value within two years, prompting Mulvany to abandon his early retirement and mount a boardroom coup to take back control last year. He had become frustrated that Benevolent had shifted from his concept of a technology company to a drug developer in its own right, with all the risk and costs associated with it.

“They brought in some luminaries,” Mulvany recalls. “Some really heavy hitters from pharma. And Benevolent morphed from a tech company to a pharma company. For me as an investor, and for some of my fellow investors, we didn’t have the appetite for that. We were technology investors.

“You had a technology shareholder base and a management and board doing biotech. All of its revenue was from its technology but it was spending a ton of money developing drugs.

“The technology cost was very low relative to drug development. So I became more of an activist shareholder at that point because it wasn’t going the way I wanted it to go and the markets reflected that too. It lost 95pc of its value.”

It’s a tale of hype meeting with financial and scientific reality that now seems to be playing out on an extreme scale as OpenAI and its rivals test the limits of pre-profit funding and investor patience. Altman alone has committed to spending more than $1tn (£750bn).

Having abandoned his retirement to mount his successful coup, Mulvany is now rebuilding Benevolent as an enterprise software company. Its new software and services are focused sharply on helping drug developers, rather than developing drugs. It’s a more commercial proposition, with a closer eye on returns for Benevolent and its big pharma customers.

“We help on the science side of things, reviewing the literature, but also how you make business decisions as a drug developer, how you expand into a particular market, how you design trials and all of that.

“People in the industry are making decisions with a fraction of the information they need.”

These are still the early days of Benevolent’s attempted comeback and Mulvany’s unexpected return from early retirement, which he had intended to spend skiing. His hopes of using the company’s targeted AI technology beyond drug discovery in fields such as defence and energy have been revived.

Benevolent, without revenue, now has the cash and investor support to pursue its new business into 2027, according to Mulvany.

Despite the mounting fears of an AI bust, he remains a believer in the technology. After a deep cull of staff, Benevolent’s coders are 50 times faster with the help of computer intelligence, for instance. But Mulvany, now an AI survivor, admits a shake-out lies ahead for those with grandiose visions.

“I saw this in the dotcom. I was there right at the bubble. But whether it’s railroads, or electricity or the internet there has always been over-investment and hype.

“So there’s going to be losers in this but the infrastructure is being put in place. So yeah, you’re seeing an AI bubble, but I’ve seen it before.”

data.title: Elon Musk’s satellite fix for mobile blackspots to cost £3 per month
data.description:
Millions of Britons will have access to mobile phone service in remote rural areas from Thursday as Elon Musk’s Starlink is rolled out for £3 a month.

The service, launched in partnership with Virgin Media O2, will boost mobile signals for O2 subscribers in remote, rural areas, allowing them to send WhatsApp messages and use apps such as maps, Find My Device and BBC Weather.

Mr Musk’s social media site X is also among a handful of compatible apps.

Customers will automatically connect to the satellite service, called O2 Satellite, which will expand the network’s coverage from 89pc to 95pc of the UK landmass, an increase roughly equivalent to an area two-thirds the size of Wales.

It will initially be available to customers with Samsung handsets, with plans to roll out to other devices, including iPhones.

O2 will charge contract customers an additional £3 a month for the service. Those on the most expensive Ultimate Plan will be able to access it for no additional cost.

The launch makes O2 the first UK mobile network to switch on its satellite service after Ofcom became the first regulator in Europe to approve the technology.

Vodafone plans to offer satellite services through its joint venture with Texas-based AST SpaceMobile. BT has struck a deal with Starlink to offer satellite broadband services and is exploring a similar tie-up for its mobile network EE.

Satellite technology has been touted as a key solution to fix patchy mobile coverage in remote, rural areas, though operators are keen to stress that it will not replace conventional mobile masts.

Mr Musk’s Starlink is also lined up to tackle poor signal on trains, while government officials are exploring its potential use in the emergency communications network used by Britain’s police, ambulance and fire services.

Starlink operates the largest satellite network for mobile services, with more than 650 satellites in low Earth orbit. Other competitors include OneWeb, which has merged with French rival Eutelsat following a £400m bailout by the UK Government, and Jeff Bezos’s Amazon Leo.

Lutz Schüler, the chief executive of Virgin Media O2, said: “This is a defining moment for UK mobile connectivity and a statement of our intent to keep innovating and ensure our customers can stay connected no matter where they are.”

Baroness Lloyd of Effra, the digital minister, said: “This is a major achievement for the UK and demonstrates leadership in next-generation connectivity.

“Being the first in Europe to launch direct-to-device satellite data services puts the UK firmly at the forefront of mobile innovation.”

data.title: AstraZeneca to invest £11bn in China after snubbing Britain
data.description:
AstraZeneca has unveiled plans to invest $15bn (£11bn) in China just months after dropping hundreds of millions of pounds of investment in Britain.

The Cambridge-based company announced the investment, which will be used to expand its medical manufacturing and research capabilities, during Sir Keir Starmer’s visit to Beijing. The Prime Minister hailed the financing as a deal that would help to support British jobs back home.

But the announcement follows a period of frosty relations between the Government and AstraZeneca which has seen the drugmaker threaten to halt investment in Britain in a row over NHS pricing.

The pharmaceutical giant, which is Britain’s biggest listed company, has abandoned plans for a £200m expansion of its Cambridge research site and £450m overhaul of its Liverpool vaccine factory.

The deal may also raise eyebrows given that five of AstraZeneca’s staff were detained by authorities in China in 2024 amid claims of potential illegal activity. The president of its China division was subsequently placed under investigation by local police, with no further details provided.

Astra is the largest drugs company in China, which is the company’s second-biggest market after the US.

Separately, AstraZeneca also announced on Friday that it had struck a deal worth as much as $18.2bn with China’s CSPC Pharmaceuticals.

Under the tie-up, AstraZeneca will have the global rights to sell CSPC’s obesity drugs outside China.

CSPC is currently developing once-monthly weight-loss jabs. The biggest weight-loss treatments currently require people to inject themselves once a week.

In total, if all of CSPC’s eight obesity drugs make it to market, AstraZeneca said the deal could be worth as much as $18.2bn – including future sales of the weight-loss treatments.

Sir Pascal Soriot, the company’s chief executive, is one of a clutch of Western business leaders who are occasionally summoned for meetings with Xi Jinping, the Chinese premier.

Sir Pascal said on Thursday: “Today’s landmark investment of $15bn begins an exciting next chapter for AstraZeneca in China, which has become a critical contributor to scientific innovation, advanced manufacturing and global public health.”

The “landmark” move was recognition of China’s growing scientific capabilities in areas that could help unlock new treatments for cancer, haematological conditions and autoimmune diseases, among others. It will be focused on sites in Bejing, Shanghai, Wuxi, Taizhou and Qingdao.

Sir Keir said: “Unlocking opportunities for British businesses across the globe and delivering for working people back home is always the driving force behind my international engagements.

“AstraZeneca’s expansion and leadership in China will help the British manufacturer continue to grow – supporting thousands of UK jobs.”

Astra has been at loggerheads with the Government over how much the NHS pays for medicines.

The company and its rivals have argued that the way the National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (Nice) evaluates “value for money” on medicines is flawed and deprives patients of potential breakthrough treatments.

For instance, Nice previously rejected Enhertu, Astra’s breast cancer drug.

Wes Streeting, the Health Secretary, walked away from talks with drugmakers last summer after failing to strike an agreement.

But in December, ministers announced a new deal with the US that saw Nice agree to pay up to 25pc more for treatments, a move aimed at protecting the UK life sciences industry.

data.title: Hope for run-down Boots as billionaire owner’s wife exits
data.description:
The British high street is experiencing its biggest cull in years.

Already reeling from a series of costly tax raids at the hands of Rachel Reeves, tough Christmas trading has proven to be the nail in the coffin for a string of struggling household names, including Claire’s, Russell & Bromley and LK Bennett. More high-profile casualties are expected in the coming weeks.

Amid the continued hollowing out of town centres, one high street stalwart remains: Boots.

Outposts of the lipstick-to-prescriptions business can still be found across the country, but many are in a sad state. After its exit from the stock market in 2007, Boots has spent the last two decades being starved of investment.

With serial dealmaker Stefano Pessina leading the charge, Boots has been allowed to dwindle – first under the ownership of private equity’s original Barbarians at the Gate, KKR, then as a forgotten overseas outpost of American pharmacy giant Walgreens.

Now Boots is in the hands of another private equity house, Sycamore Partners, after the New York-based outfit took Walgreens off the public markets last summer. Employees must fear yet more decline.

However, a shake-up at the very top of the company may signal a revival for one of Britain’s best-loved and most important retailers.

After leading the pharmacy giant for almost a decade, Boots chief executive Ornella Barra is stepping down to become chair. She replaces Pessina, who is also her business partner and husband, and is believed to still own half of the business at the ripe age of 84.

At the same time, managing director Anthony Hemmerdinger is being handed a much bigger role running Boots, including oversight of the No7 beauty brand – long regarded as one of several jewels in the stable.

The management reshuffle is viewed internally, and in the City, as another major step towards setting Boots free from its ownership purgatory and returning it to the UK stock market.

City sources said a float is still the main long-term ambition of the owners, and more likely to occur next year than in 2026.

A former executive said a spin-off of Boots “was always the plan” and the boardroom changes were “a step towards that”. The break-up of Walgreens into five standalone entities – Boots among them – shortly after its £8bn takeover last year was seen as the first real step.

The prospect of Boots being groomed for a spectacular public markets comeback under new leadership will raise hopes of a long overdue makeover of its unloved shops. Shoppers will be hoping that it also means a halt to any further closures.

The sale to Sycamore came after Boots axed 300 stores across the UK, drastically reducing its footprint from 2,200 to around 1,900 branches. Boots also shut 48 opticians in 2020, and had kickstarted a store closure plan the previous year that ended with more than 200 outlets being given the chop.

The status of Boots as more than just your typical bog-standard retailer means its future garners more attention than others.

Armed with Britain’s best-selling skincare brand No 7, the chain believes it can continue to compete in the booming beauty market despite the excitement surrounding the arrival of LVMH-backed French phenomenon Sephora in Britain, as well as other upstarts.

Amid the glamour of expensive lipstick and eyelash-thickening mascara, it is easy to forget that Boots is an integral part of the country’s healthcare system. Without its sprawling network of pharmacists, thousands of people would struggle to get their vital medicines and daily pills.

Its last round of store closures was accompanied by an apologetic statement explaining that the decision was “not taken lightly” and that in all cases there was an alternative store less than three miles away.

Yet that didn’t prevent an outcry in some affected towns, with locals complaining about being forced to endure long queues at other pharmacies, which in some cases had led to delays in getting their prescriptions.

Boots bosses have long rejected the portrayal of a business stuck in retreat as lazy and outdated.

“The Boots Group is in great shape, both financially and operationally, with Boots UK having grown market share for 19 consecutive quarters,” Barra said as she stepped aside.

But that fact masks the two-speed nature of the business. A former executive said there are around 500 Boots shops that are “the powerhouse of the business” – the vast majority of which have already been revamped.

However, the rest are much smaller shops, which are vital to the surrounding communities but cost “between £50,000 and £100,000” to refurbish with no resulting “uplift” in turnover, making it hard to justify the outlay.

“Pharmacies are really difficult to make money in now, because of what the Government pays per prescription,” another ex-director said. In November, the Department of Health and Social Care announced that NHS prescription charges would be frozen for the second year running.

 Clive Black, analyst at Shore Capital, adds: “There has been immense profiling of a small number of new and modernised stores, gaining lots of capital expenditure and senior management attention, to show the newfound vitality of Boots.

“But the reality is that many Boots are drab, under-invested, and needing of an injection of elevated execution that British shoppers will notice across the board.”

Those who know the business well say Boots branches need to become even bigger healthcare hubs, so that they can alleviate pressure on local GPs by providing more of the services that you would usually go to your doctor for.

The chain already does private online doctor consultations, vaccinations and blood pressure checks, as well as specialised treatments for skin and hair loss. However, it is eyeing a larger role in diagnostics with “at-home” testing kits for conditions such as high cholesterol, vitamin deficiencies and food intolerances. These will be offered under the mantra of standing “shoulder to shoulder with the NHS”.

If the move is successful, it would justify spending more capital on its smaller stores, many of which struggle to turn a profit.

The former executive says: “The mantra…was always ‘We’re going to have a great Boots in every major town, and none that we’re ashamed of.’ I think that will continue.”

data.title: ‘Significant’ squeeze on incomes hitting drinking, warns Guinness maker
data.description:
A “very significant” squeeze on disposable income is forcing Britons to cut back on drinking, the maker of Guinness has warned.

Diageo, which is one of Britain’s biggest pub suppliers, said the country’s economic malaise was the biggest factor in falling alcohol consumption.

Consumers are drinking “fewer servings per occasion”, the company said, although the number of times per month that people drank spirits in Britain rose by 16pc last year compared to 2024. Diageo also makes Smirnoff and Johnnie Walker.

A decline in drinking will add to pressure on Britain’s pubs, as they also grapple with tax raids and changing attitudes towards alcohol among young people.

Sir Dave Lewis, the new boss of Diageo, said: “These fewer serves per occasion point to a pressure in the economics that our consumer groups are facing.”

He added: “What you see is a very significant squeeze on disposable income.”

Sir Dave, the former boss of Tesco who was hired at the start of this year, said reinvigorating Diageo’s relationships with pubs and bars was one of his key priorities to turn around the struggling drinks maker.

He said the “on-trade” segment of its business – meaning sales into bars, restaurants, hotels and pubs – had been “dismantled understandably during Covid” but warned its “buildback has been slow and patchy”.

He was speaking as Diageo slashed its dividend in half, with Sir Dave adding there remained “significant work ahead” after he was forced to cut the company’s sales forecast.

Diageo reported a 2.8pc drop in underlying operating profits to $3.3bn (£2.4bn) in its half-year results as underlying sales also fell 2.8pc.

Sir Dave made the “difficult decision” to cut the dividend from 40.5 cents per share last year to 20 cents and ramped up cost savings to boost its flagging performance.

The prompt action helped the seasoned executive live up to his nickname “Drastic Dave”, earned during his three decades at consumer goods giant Unilever where he oversaw a programme of brutal but effective cost cuts.

However, the cost-saving plan and the weak sales wiped more than £5bn off Diageo’s market valuation on the London Stock Exchange, as shares fell by 13pc on their worst day ever.

The drinks giant also downgraded its full-year guidance for the second time in three months, with sales now expected to fall by between 2pc and 3pc because of ongoing troubles in the US. Profits are predicted to be flat or to rise by low single digits.

Sir Dave, who led a turnaround at Tesco from 2014 to 2020, said he was working on an updated strategy for Diageo, which he said he will unveil in the summer.

He was appointed at Diageo after a lengthy search for a successor to Debra Crew, who left in July following a rocky period of slipping sales and struggles to communicate a vision to both the board and market.

After performing strongly amid the rise of home drinking during the pandemic, Diageo has faced a cocktail of pressures in recent years. The company pivoted towards higher-end spirits and has battled shifting attitudes towards drinking.

More than a third of young people aged between 16 and 24 are shunning alcohol, the Health Survey for England revealed this year.

However, Guinness has attracted many new drinkers from Gen Z – driven by social media trends and growing popularity among young women.

data.title: Weight-loss drug trial results wipe £147bn off Ozempic maker
data.description:
Almost £150bn has been wiped off Ozempic drugmaker Novo Nordisk after a trial of its new weight-loss drug fell short of expectations.

Shares in the Danish pharmaceutical giant plunged by 15pc on Monday, wiping around €169bn (£147bn) off its market value in just 90 minutes.

Trading was briefly halted in Copenhagen as a result of the sharp sell-off, which drove shares to their lowest level since 2021.

It came after Novo revealed that its new obesity treatment had proven less effective than drugs made by US rival Eli Lilly.

The Danish company’s new drug CagriSema, which is delivered via a weekly injection, achieved weight loss of 23pc after 84 weeks, it said on Monday. This compares to 25.5pc for tirzepatide, the active ingredient in Eli Lilly’s weight-loss drugs Mounjaro and Zepbound.

CagriSema – a combination of the hormone cagrilintide and semaglutide, the compound in its existing drugs Ozempic and Wegovy – had been proposed as a follow-up to today’s weight-loss drugs.

However, the disappointing trial is the latest setback for Novo, which is facing fierce competition from Eli Lilly.

The company said the new drug appeared to be safe and caused only mild gastrointestinal side effects.

Novo was once Europe’s most valuable company and was briefly worth more than the entire Danish economy, but its share price has fallen back as copycat drugs grow in popularity in the US.

It is also contending with demands from Donald Trump, the US president, that pharmaceutical companies slash the cost of medication for Americans.

Novo said last year it would cut 9,000 jobs, or around 11pc of its total workforce, as part of an effort to cut 8bn Danish kroner (£930m) in costs. It has warned that profits and sales could drop by as much as 13pc this year as a result of tough competition and falling US prices.

The company’s changing fortunes have had a knock-on effect on the wider Danish economy, which has become increasingly reliant on the drugmaker.

Funds have invested billions of dollars in Novo, meaning its declining value has wiped out large chunks of Danish savers’ pensions.

The OMX Copenhagen 25 index fell as much as 3.6pc on Monday while the krone also weakened, suggesting investors were pulling funds from Denmark.

Per Hansen at Nordnet said: “Novo Nordisk’s downturn is creating negative spillover effects for other Danish stocks. It is likely foreign investors who are collectively pulling out of Danish companies.”

data.title: Warner Bros says Paramount bid may top Netflix deal
data.description:
Warner Bros has signalled it could back Paramount’s revised takeover offer before a deal already agreed with Netflix.

The Hollywood studio said on Tuesday a revamped $31-a-share offer from Paramount could “reasonably be expected” to lead to a superior proposal to a deal agreed with Netflix late last year.

Paramount’s new offer values Warner Bros at around $112bn (£83bn) and includes a promise to pay a $2.8bn termination fee that the Hollywood studio would be required to pay to Netflix for ending the current agreement.

The offer also includes a “ticking fee” of $0.25 per share for every quarter the deal doesn’t close and a $7bn termination fee if the transaction does not gain regulatory approval.

The improved bid represents a late effort by the billionaire Ellison family to derail an $83bn takeover of Warner Bros by Netflix, which was agreed in December.

Paramount, which is controlled by David Ellison and his tech billionaire father Larry Ellison, has made repeated approaches to try and force the Warner Bros board back to the table and last week won the right to make a best and final offer.

The studio behind The Godfather now appears to have made Warner Bros an offer that would be hard to refuse.

Warner Bros said the Netflix agreement remained in effect and the board would continue to recommend that transaction – a recommendation it would not withdraw or modify for now.

However, if Paramount follows through with its promised offer, the board signalled it may be deemed superior. Netflix will then have four business days to make its own counter offer.

It raises the prospect of a potentially intense takeover battle for Warner Bros, following a months-long pursuit of the studio by both bidders.

Paramount’s stock rose just more than 1pc in after-hours trading. Netflix shares also rose 1.2pc. Warner Bros Discovery shares edged down 0.8pc on the added uncertainty about any deal.

A shareholder vote on the deal is set for March 20.

Netflix has agreed to pay $27.75 per share for Warner Bros’s studio business – which is behind hits such as Harry Potter, and the HBO Max streaming service, known for Succession. Paramount’s bid also includes the studio’s traditional cable channels, such as CNN.

Paramount has stressed the regulatory risks of Netflix’s bid. The US department of justice has launched a review of the deal amid concerns that combining two major streaming services – Netflix and HBO Max – would hand the company too much power.

Netflix has downplayed concerns, though it acknowledged that the review could drag for a year and a half.

For its part, Netflix has criticised the involvement of Saudi Arabia, the United Arab Emirates and Qatar in Paramount’s bid, highlighting restrictions on free speech in the Gulf states. The Middle Eastern nations are contributing $24bn to Paramount’s bid – twice the amount committed by the Ellison family. Paramount insists the Gulf states will not have governance rights.

data.title: HSBC hands out bigger bonuses in push to rival Wall Street
data.description:
HSBC is handing its best bankers bigger bonuses as it seeks to compete with Wall Street rivals.

Senior investment bank staff received an average bonus of $819,000 (£606,000) last year, up 11pc compared with 2024. The overall pool of bonuses also increased by 10pc to $3.9bn, the highest in at least a decade.

Georges Elhedery, HSBC’s chief executive, said: “We are building a high-performance culture. It’s a culture where talent succeeds. It’s a culture where talent and performance are better rewarded and differentiated in the way we reward them.”

At the same time, HSBC reportedly intends to withhold bonuses entirely from its poorer performing staff, as it moves towards an “eat-what-you-kill” stance similar to its competitors in the US. Awarding bankers a dreaded “doughnut” – zero bonus – is seen in the industry as a humiliation.

In an attempt to improve performance and shake up the culture at the 160-year-old bank, Mr Elhedery has been swinging the axe.

The banking giant said it had cut the ranks of managing directors by 15pc over the last year, helping it meet a £1.1bn cost-cutting programme half a year early.

Many of the job losses have come from the combination of HSBC’s commercial banking, global banking and markets businesses last year. The merger led to a number of duplicated roles being axed.

Mr Elhedery, who was handed £6.62m in 2025, up from £5.58m last year, announced cost-cutting plans last year that included an 8pc reduction in payroll costs.

In total, HSBC’s employee numbers fell from 221,000 to just over 218,000 over the last year. However, pay and benefits rose from $20.2bn to $21.5bn over the same period.

The bank’s full-year results showed a pre-tax profit of $29.9bn for the year. That analysts’ estimate of $28.9bn was down 7pc compared to the prior year.

Shares in the bank rose more than 5pc on the FTSE 100.

Since taking over as chief executive, Mr Elhedery has led a radical restructuring of the bank. Along with cutting staff numbers and merging divisions, he has also doubled down on his predecessors’ focus on Asia.

The bank has shuttered some of its banking divisions in the US, the UK and Continental Europe and has taken private its troubled Hong Kong subsidiary Hang Seng Bank, as it looks to benefit from growth in the Asian financial hub.

Its business in Hong Kong saw revenue rise by 6pc to $15.9bn, while its UK division saw revenue rise by 5pc to $12.9bn.

data.title: Britain’s hapless water watchdog is asleep on the job again
data.description:
Just when you thought things couldn’t get any worse for the parched residents of Tunbridge Wells and surrounding towns, here comes Ofwat to the rescue.

With some households in the region facing their second bout of water shortages in the space of a few weeks at the hands of South East Water, some must have been praying for a miracle. Yet the comically late arrival of Britain’s regulator is the equivalent of sending in Dad’s Army.

Responsibility for the fiasco that has unfolded ultimately resides with South East Water’s equally inept, overpaid chief executive Dave Hinton and the board of nodding dog directors who have somehow seen fit to allow him to remain in post.

But for an enforced and humiliating appearance in front of a parliamentary committee of senior MPs, Hinton has been completely missing in action throughout this debacle.

Nor is this catalogue of failures a one-off. Under its current boss, South East Water has a thoroughly woeful track record of failing in its basic duty to keep the taps running for 2.3 million customers in Kent, Sussex, Surrey, Hampshire and Berkshire.

This is the second officially-declared major incident in South East Water territory in as many months, with customers in Tunbridge Wells, Kent still facing disruption after weeks. Thousands of households were also hit by shortages in 2022 and 2023.

As my colleague Patrick Galbraith and I point out in a separate piece for The Telegraph, South East Water is well on its way to claiming the crown of Britain’s worst utility from industry basket case Thames Water, which really does take some doing given its current sorry state.

Mr Hinton should have been shown the door long ago, but he’s being kept in post by the company’s unforgivably meek independent directors, led by equally absentee chairman Chris Train, who knows a thing or two about companies that fall short.

Train is also the chairman of Sellafield, which was fined for serious cybersecurity failings in 2024. The following year, the Commons Public Accounts Committee (Pac) criticised the nuclear power plant for “failure, cost-overruns and continuing safety concerns.”

Yet, the idea that Ofwat’s intervention will make much of a difference really is the stuff of fantasy.

Britain is awash with dire regulators who are meant to protect consumers from cowboy firms. The Financial Conduct Authority was branded “incompetent at best, dishonest at worst”, by MPs and peers in 2024.

Meanwhile, Pac found in 2022 that failures at Ofgem had come “at a considerable cost to billpayers” after the collapse of a staggering 29 energy suppliers in less than 18 months.

The only regulator that has shown some bite is the Competition and Markets Authority. And its reward for standing up for consumers? A thorough defanging at the hands of ministers who claimed it had become an impediment to economic growth.

Otherwise, in a crowded field, Ofwat must be a contender for the most ineffective industry policeman of all time. It is a watchdog that has repeatedly demonstrated little, if any, willingness to properly hold the industry to account, as South East knows only too well from considerable experience.

The vast bulk of Britain’s waterways have become a public health emergency, and water shortages are now commonplace – the result of extreme underinvestment in the country’s decrepit pipes and sewers by an industry that has routinely prioritised generous executive pay and investor dividends.

On every conceivable measure and metric, companies have been failing consumers on a grand scale for years.

Ultimately, the buck stops with greedy, irresponsible suppliers and shareholders. Yet, years of regulatory apathy have allowed something as basic and fundamental as the provision of drinking water to be turned into a giant and lucrative experiment in financial engineering at the expense of customers.

On the occasions when Ofwat does act, it’s like watching a snail wake up from a coma.

South East Water is already the subject of a regulatory investigation – one dating back to 2023 that still hasn’t been resolved – so what chance of a quick verdict?

As Mike Martin, the MP for Tunbridge Wells, points out: “It’s obvious that South East Water has breached the terms of the license.”

In the face of Ofwat’s impotence, is it any wonder the company has been getting away with it for ages?

Four major outages have been racked up on Hinton’s watch, and South East Water has ranked in the bottom three companies for disruptions every year since he took over.

2023 was particularly shocking, with the company recording the most interruptions and outages of any supplier in England and Wales.

Meanwhile, South East has failed to meet more than 40pc of its targets every year for the last three years. Last year, just 13 of its 38 annual targets were hit. Unsurprisingly, Ofwat penalties of a few million pounds here and there have had little effect.

Financially, it is a mess, too. Total losses since 2022 stand at £130m, the result of profits being consistently wiped out by the cost of servicing £1.3bn of borrowings. 

At times, debt interest and dividends have eclipsed the money that has been spent mending leaky pipes and other vital infrastructure.

Hinton, meanwhile, has earned nearly £2.3m since taking charge in 2020 and is in line for a 30pc pay rise, plus a £400,000 long-term “service bonus” regardless of performance. Talk about reward for failure.

It is an untenable situation that has long been crying out for a supervisor with real mettle.

Lynn Parker, senior director for enforcement at Ofwat, is right to say that “the last six weeks have been miserable for businesses and households across Kent and Sussex” – but why did it take so long for Ofwat to do anything?

Even now, it’s hard to avoid the conclusion that Ofwat only acted because Emma Reynolds, the Environment Secretary, had called publicly for it to step in.

While the regulator has dithered, senior MPs, together with Martin, have done a brilliant job of holding Hinton and colleagues to account.

Ofwat, on the other hand, is hard to take seriously. The threat of penalties, including the annulment of South East’s licence, is somewhat hollow to say the least, given the Government’s plans to abolish Ofwat, the Drinking Water Inspectorate and the Environment Agency, and replace it with a single water regulator responsible for the entire water system.

It is a welcomed move. Long-suffering customers deserve better and the disbanding of the current abject regime is a rare opportunity to create a watchdog with genuine clout. Labour cannot afford to get it wrong.

data.title: Waitrose to stop selling mackerel
data.description:
Waitrose is to stop selling mackerel because of concerns about overfishing in British waters.

The supermarket said all fresh, chilled and frozen mackerel will disappear from its counters and shelves by April 29. Pâté is also being dropped, while tinned mackerel will be available only until the current stock has sold out.

Instead, Waitrose will be promoting smoked herring and cured sea bass as “tasty alternatives”.

Waitrose is the first major UK supermarket to stop stocking mackerel. It comes after the International Council for the Exploration of the Sea, which helps governments manage their fish stocks, last year called for a 70pc reduction in mackerel fishing, warning stocks were dangerously depleted.

Jake Pickering, the head of agriculture, aquaculture and fisheries at Waitrose, said: “By suspending sourcing of mackerel at Waitrose we are reinforcing our ethical and sustainable business commitments, acting to tackle overfishing and protect the long-term health of our oceans and this crucial fish.”

Mackerel populations in the north-east Atlantic are now at their lowest level in more than 20 years.

The UK, Norway and the Faroe Islands recently agreed to cut mackerel catches by 48pc but observers have warned that this is not enough to allow populations to rebound. The European Commission warned in December that the deal “poses serious risks for the sustainability of the mackerel stock”.

Mr Pickering added: “Our customers trust us to source responsibly, and we are closely monitoring the fishery. We look forward to bringing mackerel back to our shelves once it meets our high sourcing standards.”

The supermarket said it would start stocking mackerel again if and when fish stocks recover.

Mackerel, an iridescent oily fish with a strong flavour, is high in Omega-3, which is known to be good for the human brain. However, Omega-3 oxidises very quickly, meaning that the fish goes rotten if not preserved or eaten fresh.

They are often grilled, barbecued or made into pâté. For generations, they have been an easily-caught species by children and adult anglers alike.

In Rick Stein’s fish cookery book, Fruits of the Sea, the TV chef wrote of mackerel: “The taste takes me right back to my childhood in Cornwall, when we used to go out feathering for mackerel around Padstow or the Scilly Isles.”

Because of the spoilage risk, the fish is most often sold smoked. Smoked mackerel is often turned into pâté, blended with crème fraîche or cream cheese.

“Smoked mackerel pâté is a fairly new delicacy that has become popular in the last four or five years,” Jane Grigson, the influential British cookery writer, wrote in her 1971 cookbook, Good Things.

Since then, it has become a modern classic and is often served as a dinner party canapé or starter.

Britons buy around 33,000 tonnes of mackerel a year. This is far lower than 200,000 tonnes brought ashore annually by the UK fleet, with much of Britain’s mackerel exported to France and Spain.

The UK also currently allows foreign vessels, such as Norwegian boats, to catch mackerel in British waters, which contributes to overfishing.

Almost all of Waitrose’s mackerel is sourced from Scotland.

While sales of fresh fish have stagnated in recent years, demand for tinned fish is rising. Brands such as Ortiz and Sea Sisters have proved popular with Gen Z and millennials thanks to their retro packaging and striking logos.

Waitrose said it would promote smoked herring, smoked peppered herring and smoked sea bass as mackerel alternatives.

The supermarket will also introduce frozen sardines in May as a sustainable replacement for frozen mackerel.

data.title: Statistics chief attacks BBC drama for ‘distressing’ scenes
data.description:
From drug-fuelled parties to explicit threesomes, the hit BBC drama series Industry has long flirted with controversy by portraying the most extravagant excesses of the cut-throat world of high finance.

Yet it is a fleeting reference to statisticians in the show that appears to have landed Tim Davie, the BBC’s outgoing director general, in hot water.

Darren Tierney, the permanent secretary of the Office for National Statistics (ONS), has lodged a complaint with the BBC about a recent episode of Industry that portrayed two characters gaining access to someone’s home by impersonating interviewers from the statistics body.

In a letter to Mr Davie, the ONS boss said many of his employees had expressed “distress” that their work had been “inadvertently compromised”.

Mr Tierney said the work of interviewers “depends on a foundation of trust”.

He added: “Depictions suggesting that posing as an ONS interviewer is a plausible tactic for criminal activity, even within fiction, risk undermining this delicate relationship at a time when it is already under strain.”

The ONS chief invited Mr Davie and the BBC to engage with the statistics body and “look at the challenging and vital work they do”.

Industry, which is a co-production between the BBC and HBO, has become a hit with audiences on both sides of the Atlantic for its extravagant and zeitgeisty portrayal of the lives of young City workers. It stars Marisa Abela, Kit Harington and Myha’la.

The complaint relates to an episode in the latest series that depicts two characters – Sweetpea Golightly and Harper Stern – pretending to be ONS officials to gain access to a house in Sunderland where they believe someone is inadvertently committing fraud on behalf of a major payments company.

The ONS conducts regular surveys using a team of thousands of field interviewers who visit homes to gather data for the public body.

Tina Thomas, an ONS official, said in a blog post accompanying the letter that interviewers gave advance notice of their visits and carried official ID.

She added that while staff were allowed to choose their own work attire, it was “unlikely they’ll turn up on your doorstep ... looking like a flight attendant”.

The backlash comes as the ONS faces scrutiny over the reliability of its data.

The statistics body has faced repeated criticism, including from the Bank of England, over mistakes including miscalculating inflation and overstating government borrowing by £2bn. It has also come under fire over how it collects population data, especially in areas such as gender identity and migration.

A government review last summer concluded that “deep-seated” issues had to be addressed before the statistics agency could rebuild its reputation. The review found that the blunders were in part a result of statisticians working from home.

The ONS acknowledged that there had been a sharp decline in survey response rates in recent years, which it blamed in part on fears of fraud such as the kind depicted in Industry.

Ms Thomas insisted that survey collection for the ONS had “no overlap with the backstabbing and high-pressure world of Industry”, but she added: “That’s not to say field interviewing doesn’t have its exciting moments.”

The BBC was contacted for comment.

data.title: Lloyds and Halifax customers blocked from cashing cheques at the Post Office
data.description:
Lloyds has scrapped the option for customers to deposit cheques at the Post Office despite hundreds of bank branch closures.

The banking group, which includes Halifax and Bank of Scotland and serves 28 million customers, said it removed the option last month. However, customers will still be able to withdraw and deposit cash at Post Office branches and banking hubs.

The bank renewed its commitment to the Banking Framework in December, which was introduced to safeguard customers’ access to cash. The framework comprises 30 members.

The decision to stop customers cashing in cheques at Post Office counters comes despite the lender announcing 95 more bank branch closures, in addition to 49 already earmarked to shut this year. Lloyds Banking Group has closed 1,470 sites in the past decade, according to consumer group Which?.

A Lloyds spokesman said that customers could use the bank’s mobile app to scan cheques and added that “very few people choose to deposit cheques at the Post Office”.

However, campaigners warned the change could isolate elderly customers and those in rural areas.

Cheryl Cottle-Hunkin, a councillor for Devon, said: “People are feeling really anxious as a lot of them are not able to use technology. They’re travelling very long distances to find a branch.”

Under the latest round of closures, 53 Lloyds, 31 Halifax and 11 Bank of Scotland sites will shut between May this year and March 2027.

This is in addition to an ongoing closure programme that will shut 49 sites by October.

Ms Cottle-Hunkin added: “Decisions are often made by people living in urban areas – they don’t realise the impact on rural communities. We haven’t even got public transport in many areas. This will hit vulnerable people the hardest.”

Andrew Haggar, of comparison website MoneyComms, warned that small businesses still received cheques, and would now face long journeys to deposit them.

He said: “It’s a double whammy for customers, with all the [branch] closures. For a small business, this is just not practical. When closing down branches, safety nets should be in place.”

The Financial Conduct Authority states that banks must assess customer impact when closing branches, and provide reasonable alternatives for cash access.

More than 6,300 branches have closed in the past decade. Currently, 40 out of the UK’s 650 constituencies don’t have any branches, while 88 are down to their last one, according to data from consumer group Which?.

Banking hubs, run by the Post Office and funded by high-street banks, were designed to act as a safety net for isolated customers to access cash.

There are 250 hubs across the UK, with plans to expand to 350 by the end of the current parliament. However, the national rollout of hubs has been hit by delays, and critics have labelled their facilities “inadequate”.

data.title: Don’t leave me over Epstein links, Baroness de Rothschild urges bank clients
data.description:
Ariane de Rothschild has sought to reassure the clients of her private Swiss bank over her links to Jeffrey Epstein.

The billionaire French banking chief executive of Edmond de Rothschild Group, 60, was in close contact with Epstein from 2013 until 2019, the year he died in a federal jail cell in Manhattan while awaiting trial on sex trafficking charges.

The Baroness, who was revealed to be a confidante of the paedophile in the latest tranche of Epstein files, has insisted her connections and now-public exchanges with him do not undermine “my integrity or the integrity of our group’s activities”.

It is understood that the family-owned private bank and asset management firm, of which Baroness de Rothschild is also chairman, is seeking to reassure spooked clients after the revelations, which have prompted widespread concern about its leadership.

She said in a letter to customers: “Our group is about to announce very solid results with a robust balance sheet and high-quality capital.”

‘Clearly false or altered’

In the letter, seen by The Telegraph, the Baroness added: “I am confident in the future of our group. Please be assured of my determination, and that of my teams, to support you over the long term. I would like to thank you once again for your trust.”

Sources claimed the climate was “extremely tense” inside the bank, which managed around 184bn Swiss francs (£175bn) between its private banking and asset management arms in 2024.

One client said: “If the bank is affected legally or financially, that puts me at risk. If management accepted or overlooked this type of association, how can integrity be guaranteed?”

In her letter, Baroness de Rothschild, who has a personal fortune estimated at €5.3bn (£4.62bn), insisted that her private exchanges with Epstein were “made public without context or chronology,” adding that the release included “elements that are clearly false or altered”.

She explained that the pair were introduced in 2013 by Terje Rod Larsen, a Norwegian former deputy prime minister, who she said was “internationally recognised at the time for his role in the Oslo Accords”.

Referring to Epstein, Baroness de Rothschild added: “This introduction took place in a context when he was regarded as an influential businessman among senior international decision-makers and officials.”

The files released by the US justice department have shed light on the international and powerful web of influence the financier had established in his lifetime, ranging from top politicians to the global glitterati.

The latest release of three million documents in late January showed Baroness de Rothschild consulting Epstein repeatedly and on a range of topics, including asking his advice to help navigate a private legal battle with other members of her family as well as to allegedly complain about her late husband, Benjamin.

She became a member of one of Europe’s most prominent banking dynasties after her marriage in 1999, and took over as sole manager of the family business following de Rothschild’s death in 2021, aged 57, from a heart attack.

One email exchange between her and Epstein, dated the day after Britain voted to leave the European Union, she remarked: “We both know why we so dislike the Brits ! What a mess ! At least, we’ll keep trading volatility for a while.”

‘Bring the girls’

Another in 2017 showed Epstein asking the mother-of-four whether her daughters had the “HPV [Human Papillomavirus] shots,” saying he has “all the assitants [sic] get a full health check”, to which she responded that they did.

In another, he urged her to “bring the girls” – likely a reference to her four daughters – to his Little Saint James island, and informed her about a trip to Cuba, which he said he was organising for November 2017. They frequently coordinated diaries and timings for potential meet-ups around the globe and conversations over the phone.

In the letter to clients, she added that she and her daughters had been “deeply hurt and shocked by the scandalous accusations directed at us, particularly on social media”.

She went on: “The violence of certain shortcuts and unfounded accusations contributes to a climate one might have thought belonged to another time.”

The banker explained that Epstein facilitated introductions for her and that she “discovered the reality and extent of the crimes committed by J. Epstein and his entourage at the same time as the general public”.

“I say this without any ambiguity – as a mother, as CEO and as a shareholder – these acts are of extreme gravity and I condemn them in the strongest possible terms,” she added, saying: “I would like once again to express my sincere compassion to the victims of J. Epstein.”

data.title: Taxpayer on the hook for millions as solar company faces administration
data.description:
Taxpayers are facing a potential multimillion-pound blow as a leading British solar energy developer risks the threat of administration.

Hive Energy is preparing to appoint administrators just months after securing a £60m taxpayer-backed loan from HSBC to launch itself as a global operation.

The loan was announced by the UK Government last November at the UN’s COP30 climate conference to show how the UK was supporting the global expansion of solar. The loan guarantee was personally endorsed by Tim Reid, the chief executive of UK Export Finance Agency (UKEF), who said he was “proud” to support Hive.

It is the second such loan offered to Hive Energy, following a similar guarantee for a £19m loan from Santander taken out in 2024.

This week Hive issued a “notice of intention to appoint administrators” with law firm DLA Piper as its legal advisors. The move suggests the company – which has 200 renewables projects in its global pipeline, 15 of which are in the UK – is at risk of collapse.

It also raises the threat that taxpayers could be on the hook for loan repayments, and questions about the quality of UKEF’s vetting of Hive before approving the latest loan.

When asked by The Telegraph if taxpayer money was at risk, the UKEF and Mr Reid declined to comment.

HSBC and Santander banks also both declined to comment.

Hive Energy, which was founded by city entrepreneur and ocean racing yachtsman Giles Redpath, confirmed that it was suffering problems with creditors linked to its subsidiary Ethical Power, which constructs and operates solar and other renewables sites across the UK, Spain, Italy, Greece and New Zealand.

A spokesman said: “This process does not mean that the business has entered administration or that it will enter administration, but rather provides time and stability to explore strategic options in an orderly manner.

“This is not a decision to cease trading, and it does not change our day-to-day operations or the ongoing development of our projects.”

Hampshire-based Hive Energy was founded by Mr Redpath, a former telecoms entrepreneur, in 2010 to exploit the surging interest in solar and other renewable energy.

The latest accounts, covering the year to March 2024, describe Hive as operating in 20 different countries through 180 subsidiary companies – most of which are linked to particular renewables projects.

Its UK projects include the Cleve Hill solar park, the UK’s largest operational solar and battery storage facility on marshes on Kent’s north coast prized by locals as a wildlife refuge.

Mr Redpath is also the driving force behind the $5.8bn (£4.2bn) Hive Hydrogen project in South Africa, as well as similar large-scale hubs in Spain and Chile. These projects aim to produce green ammonia for the global shipping and fertiliser industries.

Piling losses and loans

Company accounts from 2024, the last published, show Hive has two directors but that Mr Redpath has a majority shareholding.

The company made an operating loss of £29m in that year, but sold off assets worth £37m, paying the resulting dividends of about £7.4m to “a director, their wife and children”.

The same accounts state that Hive’s “directors and shareholders” had borrowed a further £7.2m from the company.

Outside the boardroom Mr Redpath is a renowned racing yachtsman, well-known for competing in races around the British Isles and across the Atlantic. In 2023, he commissioned a £5m racing multihull called Jack.

UKEF said last November it had guaranteed the £60m bank loan to Hive to help it scale up solar power projects across Europe, North America, the Caribbean, South America and Africa.

At the time, Mr Reid said: “We’re proud to continue supporting British businesses like Hive Energy, which reinforce the UK’s position as a leader in the global transition to clean energy.”

A Hive spokesman said: “Hive Energy is a long-term investor in the Ethical Power group of companies. That group has been undertaking a significant restructuring process.

“During this period, Hive (which has supported Ethical through both funding and guarantees) has experienced some creditor pressure in relation to several Ethical construction projects, creating a risk of enforcement action.”

The spokesman added: “In light of this, the Board of Hive has filed a Notice of Intention to appoint administrators to … provide a short period of statutory protection and stability.”

“Hive is a long-standing and fundamentally strong business and … continues to trade under the control of its existing Board and management team, as do all companies within the Hive Group.”

Ethical Power said: “Ethical Power is not affected by these actions as Hive Energy is a shareholder and not a parent/holding company. Ethical Power continues its operations, delivering projects and receiving payments from clients.”

data.title: Fire Biden-linked board member or face ‘consequences’, Trump tells Netflix
data.description:
Donald Trump has demanded that Netflix sack a board member or “pay the consequences” after she warned Democrats would punish companies that “take a knee” to the president.

Susan Rice, who served in both Joe Biden, the former US president, and Barack Obama’s administrations, said companies that had kowtowed to Mr Trump would be “held accountable”, prompting the president to call for her to be fired “immediately”.

The row threatens to jeopardise the streaming giant’s planned $83bn (£60bn) takeover of Warner Bros, which must be approved by US regulators because of competition concerns.

Ms Rice said on a podcast that news organisations and law firms that had gone along with Mr Trump’s demands for loyalty would be “held accountable” if the Democrats returned to power.

She added: “If they think Democrats are going to play by the old rules, they’ve got another thing coming.”

Laura Loomer, an activist and a well-known Trump supporter seen as the standard bearer for the Maga movement, accused Ms Rice of “threatening half of the country with weaponised government and political retribution for choosing who they wanted to vote for as president”.

She added: “This is as anti-American as it gets, and Netflix is proving every day they are an anti-American, WOKE company.”

Responding to that message on Truth Social, Mr Trump said Netflix should fire “Trump Deranged Susan Rice, IMMEDIATELY, or pay the consequences”.

The US president wrote: “She’s got no talent or skills – purely a political hack! HER POWER IS GONE, AND WILL NEVER BE BACK. How much is she being paid, and for what??? Thank you for your attention to this matter.”

Ms Rice rejoined Netflix’s board in 2023 after leaving the Biden administration.

The threat of “consequences” is likely to alarm Ted Sarandos, Netflix co-chief executive, who is in a fiercely contested bidding war with Paramount to buy Warner Bros.

Netflix has reached an agreement with Warner Bros on a combination but the Hollywood studio last week reopened talks with Paramount, which has been stressing the regulatory risks of the Netflix deal.

A merger would need to be approved by US authorities as it would hand Netflix a third of the subscription video-on-demand market, and 23pc of US streaming revenue.

It would also allow the streaming giant to bundle its existing service with Warner Bros’s soon-to-be-launched HBO Max, – a move Netflix said would reduce streaming prices.

It emerged on Saturday that the US department of justice was also investigating whether Netflix wielded anticompetitive leverage when acquiring content.

Mr Trump said the deal could be “a problem” in December and told reporters he would personally be involved in the decision.

However, in a more recent interview with NBC he appeared to backtrack, saying: “I’ve been called by both sides. It’s the two sides, but I’ve decided I shouldn’t be involved. The Justice Department will handle it.”

He added: “There’s a theory that one of the companies is too big and it shouldn’t be allowed to do it, and the other company is saying something else.

“They’re beating the hell out of each other – and there’ll be a winner.”

Paramount is controlled by the billionaire Ellison family, who has close ties to Mr Trump. Meanwhile, Mr Sarandos has sought to court the president over the deal, securing a White House meeting with Mr Trump in the weeks before the deal with Warner Bros was agreed.

Netflix has been approached for comment.

data.title: The green power revolution causing earthquakes across Cornwall
data.description:
The promise of underground riches is nothing new in Cornwall. But on Thursday, the region will plumb new depths in the quest to harness Britain’s natural resources.

For the first time, the United Downs deep geothermal power plant will start generating 24/7 electricity at a site near Redruth.

With an output of around three megawatts, enough to power roughly 10,000 homes, the plant cannot exactly be described as game-changing.

Yet experts believe it will help pave the way for similar projects across Britain aimed at tapping into the vast thermal resources below our feet.

The United Downs project, developed by Geothermal Engineering Ltd (GEL), will draw water at temperatures of around 190C from underground reservoirs that sit approximately five kilometres beneath the surface.

It takes advantage of a natural fault line using two wells, one that draws water up and one that pumps it back into the granite rock formations. Water that is brought above ground is run through a heat exchanger which uses another liquid with a lower boiling point to make steam and drive a turbine.

The result is power that is nearly always on – whatever the weather – save for short maintenance periods, says Ryan Law, the chief executive of GEL.

“Once you have done your drilling and the rest of it, the plant then runs 24/7 for about 96pc of the year,” he says.

In renewable energy, these kinds of numbers are virtually unheard of. Utility-scale solar tends to only push 25pc of the year while wind farms tend to land somewhere between 20pc and 40pc.

Meanwhile, thanks to modern breakthroughs in drilling technologies made by oil and gas fracking companies in the US, geothermal projects are also becoming cheaper to develop.

“There have been some quite big leaps forward,” says Law. “What has come from the last 10 years of developments in the US has very much enabled geothermal drilling to be performed faster and more precisely, while there’s much greater availability of rigs as well.

“That combination has helped to reduce the costs and it has made our sort of project, which is drilling down five kilometres into granite – pretty hard rock – much more feasible.”

Like fracking, however, this kind of drilling can cause unnerving mini-earthquakes.

In Britain, ministers effectively outlawed fracking for oil and gas when they limited operations that create tremors of more than a 0.5 magnitude.

There are no such rules for geothermal, even though it has caused mini-tremors that were three times more powerful than this, with the industry instead regulated based on its surface vibrations. Law argues that this is more sensible because it measures the actual effects above ground.

Nevertheless, the results can still be scary. For two days in 2020, GEL induced 15 mini-quakes of magnitudes up to 1.5 as it was carrying out drilling at United Downs. Residents reported their windows rattled while some likened it to heavy thunderstorms.

To soothe concerns from nearby residents, GEL gave little “Raspberry Shake” seismographs – powered by Raspberry Pi computers – to local schools so that children and their families could learn about the project for themselves. Most have since accepted that the effects are harmless, Law claims.

“Because we’re the first one, not many people knew what on earth we were doing,” he says.

“Some people thought we were secretly drilling for oil and gas. Some thought we were secretly dumping nuclear waste. So we had to do an education programme about what seismicity is.”

United Downs is blazing a trail by generating power, but most experts think geothermal’s biggest potential is in heating and cooling.

The technology already provides the basis for domestic ground-source heat pumps.

Advocates believe it could be used on a much grander scale to heat entire city districts by tapping into underground reservoirs or even abandoned mine shafts that have been left filled with water.

The areas of biggest potential include Cornwall – where huge amounts of radioactive granite underground provide a massive, humming source of heat – as well as the North West of England, Scotland and Yorkshire.

“It varies across the UK by depth and by location, depending on the geology, but there is huge theoretical potential,” says Dr Alison Monaghan, the head of geothermal at the British Geological Survey (BGS).

The BGS has estimated the UK has about 200 exajoules of “accessible” geothermal heat – enough to meet the entire country’s heating demand for 100 years.

In some places, such as the Cheshire and Wessex basins, it is possible to extract heat by dredging up water trapped underground in spongy layers of sandstone and limestone and stripping out the heat before returning it.

Elsewhere, there is even more heat to be had from areas sitting atop granite such as Cornwall.

“I’ve been doing this for about seven or eight years and there’s definitely been a huge increase in interest in geothermal energy recently,” says Monaghan.

“It’s driven by a number of factors, from the decarbonisation of heat to energy security.

“Geothermal is very decentralised – you don’t need a huge power station in one place. Instead, you can have different scales of geothermal energy in different places and so you’re kind of distributing your energy system.”

At United Downs, there is another more material attraction as well: The site is pioneering the mining of lithium – the metal known as “white gold”, which is used in batteries – through a new form of extraction from briny water.

The brine from the site boasts a lithium concentration of about 360 parts per million, among the highest rates in Europe.

This combination of power and mineral extraction has helped to make the scheme economically attractive – and also meant GEL was able to tap £1.8m in government support for critical mineral supply chains, along with a £119-per-megawatt-hour contract for difference.

The company is planning two other similar lithium and power projects nearby and expects them to have a combined output of almost 20,000 tonnes of lithium carbonate by 2030.

That is about one quarter of the upper demand estimate for the various battery gigafactories that have been announced around the country, including plants expected to serve carmakers Nissan and Jaguar Land Rover.

There are also hopes that rare earths could be produced there one day.

Fortunately for residents, though, Law says there will be no open pits or vast mine sites. The company’s only footprint is a low-lying production plant on an industrial estate.

“We don’t have to do any mining, we don’t have to do any digging, we don’t have to excavate,” he says. “The water is just full of lithium – and we’re just bringing bucket loads of the stuff to the surface every second.”

For this reason, along with the power being generated on site, he believes the project can remain price-competitive with foreign lithium producers.

Meanwhile, Octopus Energy, Britain’s biggest household electricity supplier, has already agreed to purchase power from the project.

If all of this was not already appealing enough for Ed Miliband, the Energy Secretary, Law says that geothermal has another potential bonus.

It relies heavily on the same expertise as Britain’s North Sea oil and gas industry, which critics have accused Mr Miliband of hastening to an early grave.

“Everything we have done subsurface used skill-sets, materials, steel and pumps from Aberdeen,” Law adds.

“So for us, it’s been a major advantage to have one of the best [oil and gas service] centres in the world within the UK because we have access to all of that.

“We obviously don’t want to see that industry go and we’d like to give people as many jobs as we can in our sector.”

data.title: NHS to pay £3bn more for drugs to escape Trump tariffs
data.description:
The NHS has agreed to pay 25pc more for new medicines to escape Donald Trump’s sweeping new tariffs on drugs.

The US president unveiled a new pharmaceutical trade deal with Britain on Monday, striking an agreement to impose zero import tariffs on medical products from the UK.

It will see British medicines carved out from sweeping new levies, offering a major boost for one of Britain’s biggest exports to America. In 2024, the UK exported around £6.6bn in pharmaceutical and medical products to the US.

The agreement includes a pledge for the NHS to increase the net price it pays for new medicines by 25pc, which will add around £3bn to the taxpayer’s £12bn annual medical spending bill. This will be phased in.

It follows weeks of uncertainty over the future of the industry. In August, the US president threatened to impose tariffs of up to 250pc on all pharmaceutical imports – including the UK.

In September, he said there would be 100pc tariffs on “any branded or patented Pharmaceutical Product” coming into the US from October 1. At the time, he said companies could get an exemption if they had started building factories in the US.

While the White House has agreed to a spate of country-specific trade deals over the past year, pharma tariffs are expected to fall outside the scope of these agreements.

Under the new agreement, the NHS has also committed to slashing rebates that drug companies have to pay on sales of newer medicines to the health service.

The so-called Voluntary Scheme for Branded Medicines Pricing, Access and Growth (VPAG) is designed to cap the overall NHS drug bill but pharmaceutical companies have complained it has failed to keep pace with inflation.

Additionally, the deal means the UK will cut the rebate rate from 22.9pc to 15pc in 2026.

It is also understood that the Government will increase the threshold that determines which treatments are available on the NHS, boosting the spending cap on certain medicines and paving the way for more cutting-edge treatments to be introduced.

Drug giants have long complained over the decades-old formula used to determine whether medicines are deemed value for money, claiming this does not allow them to get the best new drugs into the NHS.

Jamieson Greer, the US trade representative, said: “For too long, American patients have been forced to subsidise prescription drugs and biologics in other developed countries by paying a significant premium for the same products in ours.

“Today, the United States and the United Kingdom announce this negotiated outcome pricing for innovative pharmaceuticals, which will help drive investment and innovation in both countries.”

He added: “The Trump Administration is reviewing the pharmaceutical pricing practices of many other US trading partners and hopes that they will follow suit with constructive negotiations.”

Howard Lutnick, the US commerce secretary, said the deal would bring new jobs to America.

Mr Lutnick said: “This deal doesn’t just deepen our economic partnership with the United Kingdom – it ensures that the breakthroughs of tomorrow will be built, tested and produced on American soil.”

The White House has previously made clear its frustration over the lack of spending on innovative medicines in Britain. Currently, the UK spends just 0.28pc of its GDP on new medicines, roughly a third of what America does.

Britain previously pledged to review the health service’s drug pricing to take into account “the concerns of the president” under the UK-US trade deal struck in May.

Mr Trump has called for an end to overseas countries “freeloading” on American innovation, singling out Britain for a place where medicine prices are unfairly low compared to the US.

The US ambassador last month said Britain needed to change how it priced medicines or risk more global drug companies scrapping investments in the UK.

Merck, one of America’s largest drug companies, this year ditched plans to open a £1bn research centre in London, while AstraZeneca has paused £200m spending on its Cambridge research facility.

Liz Kendall, the Science and Technology Secretary, said the deal would “enable and incentivise life sciences companies to continue to invest and innovate right here in the UK”.

Chris Boerner, chief executive of Bristol Myers Squibb, said the trade agreement meant the pharmaceutical company will invest “upwards of $500m (£378m)” over the next five years.

Mr Boerner said: “This investment will come across multiple areas of the business including research, development and manufacturing. This agreement is a sign of progress and one that creates an environment conducive to our continued presence in the UK.”

data.title: British Gas owner seeks to extend nuclear plants’ lifespans into 2030s
data.description:
British Gas owner Centrica is planning to keep its oldest nuclear plants running into the 2030s to help strengthen the UK’s energy supplies.

The FTSE 100 giant said on Thursday that it supported plans to extend the lifespan of its fleet of 1980s power stations and was “increasingly confident” that such a move would be granted.

The company also revealed that profits almost halved from £1.55bn to £814m last year as gas and power prices tumbled and bosses bet on a major investment in the future Sizewell C nuclear plant. It has pledged to commit up to £600m on the project by the end of 2028.

Shares in Centrica plunged by more than 9pc following the update, wiping more than £800m off its market value.

Along with France’s EDF, the energy giant is a shareholder in all five of Britain’s remaining nuclear sites.

Of these, four advanced gas-cooled reactor (AGR) sites are currently scheduled to shut between 2028 and 2030 – Hartlepool, Heysham One, Heysham Two and Torness – while the fifth plant, Sizewell B, is expected to be extended into the 2050s.

However, the Government warned last month that the AGR closures risked leaving “a dangerous gap in Britain’s low-carbon energy supply” because they would happen before new plants came online. It said it supported safely extending them if possible.

Chris O’Shea, the chief executive of Centrica, said on Thursday that Hartlepool and Heysham One were currently due to shut in 2028 while Torness and Heysham Two were due to shut by 2030.

However, he added: “We are increasingly confident that we will see lifetime extensions so that all of those plants can go into the early 2030s.

“Probably you will see a number of one or two-year extensions there.”

Extensions for Hartlepool and Heysham One could be announced later this year, he said.

EDF confirmed last month it had “an ambition to generate low carbon electricity from all four generating AGR stations for as long as it is safe and commercially viable to do so”.

The French company added: “Now the stations are in the latter stages of their generating lives, further extensions will not be for long.

“We will keep their lifetimes under review to assess whether further life extensions can be achieved.”

EDF said their lifespans will ultimately depend on safety inspections of their graphite cores.

Over time, the cores develop cracks that can prevent the reactor’s control rods from being operated properly. EDF has previously stressed that safety rules mean it would have to decommission the plant long before enough of the rods became inoperable.

Any extension would have to be supported by the Office for Nuclear Regulation, an independent quango.

The plant closures would mean Britain’s nuclear power output would tumble to between just three to four gigawatts by 2030, down from six gigawatts today and a peak of 12.7 gigawatts in the mid-1990s.

Two new power plants, Hinkley Point C in Somerset and Sizewell C in Suffolk, are under construction but won’t come online until the early 2030s and late 2030s, respectively.

Sir Keir Starmer said earlier this year that the Government wanted to “avoid a ‘nuclear gap’ by enabling existing stations to continue running where demonstrably safe, such as through the potential 20-year lifetime extension of Sizewell B and by getting Hinkley Point C and Sizewell C online as soon as possible”.

Centrica blamed its drop in profits on “challenging” market conditions but pointed to “bold investments” in projects such as Sizewell C that would bring future revenues.

European gas prices peaked at about €56 (£49) per megawatt hour in 2025 before tumbling by about 50pc through the rest of the year.

Centrica said the annual loss also included a reappraisal of energy trading contracts that cost £700m, a £500m write-down on “late-life” gas fields and costs related to investment in its nuclear portfolio.

The company said it was increasing the dividend by 22pc but was pausing its share buyback programme.
